headline: Love of a Raspberry Tart
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 911 Recordings of Gunman During Orlando Nightclub Siege Are Released
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The 911 call began with about six seconds of Arabic, and then Omar Mateen switched to English: “I want to let you know, I’m in Orlando, and I did the shooting.”

headline: Bundy Verdict Puts a Target on the Backs of Federal Workers
text: ESCALANTE, Utah — With the jury acquittals last week of Ammon and Ryan Bundy and their accomplices in the 41-day armed takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon last winter, the lives of federal land managers in the American West got a whole lot more difficult.

headline: Where Mountains of Halloween Candy Go, the Morning After
text: Overwhelmed by candy?

headline: What Happens to the Markets if Donald Trump Wins?
text: Assume, for a moment, that Donald J. Trump wins the presidency.

headline: James Comey’s Big Mistake
text: Four days after James Comey, the F.B.I. director, sent Congress a brief, inscrutable, election-shaking letter about emails that may or may not be new or relevant to the previously concluded investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private email server, his logic makes even less sense than it did on Friday.

headline: Zcash, a Harder-to-Trace Virtual Currency, Generates Price Frenzy
text: Speculators are snapping up a new virtual currency known as Zcash that was designed by university academics and built to be all but untraceable.

headline: Bridge Case Verdict May Hinge on Officials Who Weren’t Tried
text: NEWARK — Prosecutors opened the case against two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with a stunning assertion: The governor himself knew during the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge that they were meant to punish a mayor for declining to endorse him.

headline: Donald Trump's Lawyers' Warnings on Tax Maneuver
text: Mr. Trump's own lawyers at Willkie Farr & Gallagher cautioned him about using a a tax avoidance maneuver in the 1990s.

headline: How Donald Trump Avoided Paying Taxes Using Other People’s Money
text: Mr. Trump managed to save millions in personal taxes by borrowing – then losing – other people’s money.

headline: Donald Trump Used Legally Dubious Method to Avoid Paying Taxes
text: Donald J. Trump proudly acknowledges he did not pay a dime in federal income taxes for years on end. He insists he merely exploited tax loopholes legally available to any billionaire — loopholes he says Hillary Clinton failed to close during her years in the United States Senate. “Why didn’t she ever try to change those laws so I couldn’t use them?” Mr. Trump asked during a campaign rally last month.

headline: A.P. Poll About to Take a Back Seat to College Football Playoff Rankings
text: For the past three weeks, No. 1 Alabama has claimed 60 of the 61 first-place votes in the weekly Associated Press college football poll. The only dissenter has stubbornly stuck with No. 2 Michigan.

headline: ‘Going Flat’ After Breast Cancer
text: Before Debbie Bowers had surgery for breast cancer, her doctor promised that insurance would pay for reconstruction, and said she could “even go up a cup size.” But Ms. Bowers did not want a silicone implant or bigger breasts.

headline: For the Clintons, Two Investigations, One Protective Reflex
text: Bill and Hillary Clinton argued that the man in charge of the investigation had grossly overreached. He had been motivated by politics rather than public service. And he had no damaging information to support his relentless pursuit and the daily negative headlines it generated.

headline: James Comey Role Recalls Hoover’s F.B.I., Fairly or Not
text: WASHINGTON — Since President Obama named James B. Comey director of the F.B.I. in 2013, the 6-foot-8 former prosecutor has spoken often of dark chapters in the bureau’s history, notably J. Edgar Hoover’s order to wiretap the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and use the tapes to try to drive the civil rights leader to suicide.

headline: World Series Drawing Most Viewers Since Red Sox’ Sweep in ’04
text: Through five games, the World Series between the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians has attracted the most viewers for the Series since 2004, when the Boston Red Sox swept the St. Louis Cardinals to win their first title in 86 years.

headline: Confidence Even as Hillary Clinton’s Momentum Slows
text: WASHINGTON — The announcement that the F.B.I. is reviewing newly discovered emails of a top Hillary Clinton aide has slowed the campaign’s momentum and the hopes of expanding support in traditional Midwestern battleground states. Leading Democratic strategists say the news has caused some of Mrs. Clinton’s more casual supporters to drift away.

headline: Investigating Donald Trump, F.B.I. Sees No Clear Link to Russia
text: WASHINGTON — For much of the summer, the F.B.I. pursued a widening investigation into a Russian role in the American presidential campaign. Agents scrutinized advisers close to Donald J. Trump, looked for financial connections with Russian financial figures, searched for those involved in hacking the computers of Democrats, and even chased a lead — which they ultimately came to doubt — about a possible secret channel of email communication from the Trump Organization to a Russian bank.

headline: Defense, Though Hard to Gauge, Gives Cubs a Clear Edge
text: CLEVELAND — Defense does not usually get top billing in baseball, and it remains one of the harder aspects of the game to measure. But in Game 5 of the World Series on Sunday night, the Chicago Cubs put on a display of stellar fielding that was hard to overlook and highlighted how important good glove work can be to a team’s success.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This city is broken in some ways. We have decided that rather than confront the disagreements and the differences of opinion, we’ll simply annihilate the person who disagrees with us.”

headline: In 1997, an Indians Title Was Put in Writing, Until the Story Changed
text: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland Indians remain one victory from winning their first World Series in 68 years. But in an alternate universe, the Indians’ wait for another championship is not nearly that long.

headline: Norman Brokaw, Agent to Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley, Dies at 89
text: Norman Brokaw, who rose from teenage mail clerk to top mogul at the William Morris talent agency, where he broke ground in the fledgling television industry for idled Hollywood stars and a black stand-up comic named Bill Cosby, died on Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Curly Putman, Writer of ‘The Green, Green Grass of Home,’ Dies at 85
text: Curly Putman, a songwriter whose teary ballad with a twist ending, “The Green, Green Grass of Home,” became a worldwide hit for Tom Jones in 1967, and whose long string of country classics included “D-I-V-O-R-C-E” for Tammy Wynette and “He Stopped Loving Her Today” for George Jones, died on Sunday at his home in Lebanon, Tenn. He was 85.

headline: Launch a Thousand Ships
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — We get mail here at Wordplay, and some of it is from readers who wonder exactly how constructors come up with their ideas. It’s a fair question, but not one that’s easy to answer.

headline: Choi Soon-sil, at Center of Political Scandal in South Korea, Is Jailed
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The woman at the center of President Park Geun-hye’s worst leadership crisis was jailed on Tuesday, as prosecutors grilled her overnight over allegations that she had manipulated important government affairs from the shadows.

headline: A Survivor With a Steely Resolve That Can Inspire and Inflame
text: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton. He is the showman who played to his audience. She is the survivor who kept going after the prize. It has been a four-year journey to a signal chapter in American history. A week ahead of Election Day, here is our essay on how Mrs. Clinton has taken many punches but has seemed to always come back stronger and smarter, delighting her supporters and irking her detractors. (Read our essay on Mr. Trump, too.)

headline: A Showman With an Anger That Ignites, and Limits, His Appeal
text: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton. He is the showman who played to his audience. She is the survivor who kept going after the prize. It has been a four-year journey to a signal chapter in American history. A week ahead of Election Day, here is our essay on how Mr. Trump’s use of “we” in his speeches — “We’re going to build a wall” — helped him connect with voters until his attacks and boasts came back to haunt him. (Read our essay on Mrs. Clinton, too.)

headline: Producers of ‘Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812’ Offer to Settle Dispute
text: Seeking to end an acrimonious dispute that has cast a shadow over one of this fall’s most promising new Broadway musicals, the producers of “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” offered on Monday to settle litigation with the nonprofit that commissioned the show.

headline: Americans Blame Obesity on Willpower, Despite Evidence It’s Genetic
text: Americans believe that obesity is tied with cancer as the biggest health threat in the nation today. But though scientific research shows that diet and exercise are insufficient solutions, a large majority say fat people should be able to summon the willpower to lose weight on their own.

headline: Corrections: November 1, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Fresh Off the Boat’ and Louis C.K. on ‘Conan’
text: “Fresh Off the Boat” takes on illegal immigration in a story centered on the 1996 presidential election. The Science Channel investigates how playing video games affects your brain. And Louis C.K. takes the stage of the Apollo Theater on “Conan.”

headline: Hillary Clinton, Michel Aoun, Mosul: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Audemars Piguet on Display in Shanghai
text: With some 200 timepieces on display until Nov. 13, “To Break the Rules, You Must First Master Them,” an exhibition at the Yuz Museum in Shanghai, is Audemars Piguet’s largest display ever staged outside Switzerland.

headline: François-Paul Journe’s Motto? ‘He Invented It and Made It.’
text: François-Paul Journe is an independent watchmaker who is not afraid to speak his mind, even if it means speaking out against the giants of the Swiss watchmaking industry.

headline: A Family Affair: McGonigle Watches
text: John and Stephen McGonigle’s house was full of clocks when they were growing up in rural Ireland. Their father, a compositor at the Irish Times, had a gift for fixing timepieces and word spread. “Every flat surface had a clock on it,” John recalled. “And instead of pictures, we had other people’s clocks on the walls.”

headline: Reviving Fears for a New Generation of Watch Fans
text: When Nicholas Bowman-Scargill’s mother made a joke at a Sunday lunch about restarting the family’s 170-year-old Fears watch business, he laughed. The company closed 60 years ago, and its revival wasn’t something he had thought much about.

headline: For Melinda Gates, Birth Control Is Women’s Way Out of Poverty
text: Melinda Gates has made providing poor women in developing countries access to contraception a mission. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which she leads with her husband, has donated more than $1 billion for family planning efforts and will spend about $180 million more this year.

headline: Ford Reaches Tentative Deal With Union in Canada
text: OTTAWA — Unifor, Canada’s largest private sector union, reached a tentative agreement with the Ford Motor Company of Canada early Tuesday, concluding contract talks with the three Detroit-based automakers.

headline: The Female Gaze in Fashion Photography
text: An exhibit at PhotoVogue Festival in Milan explores how female photographers are redefining the concept of beauty in fashion images.

headline: Surprise: A Trade Deal Wins Approval
text: The new trade agreement between Canada and the European Union, negotiated over seven years, was finally signed on Sunday after 11th-hour concessions to a rebellious Belgian region that had threatened to kill the entire deal. The question now is whether the agreement spells hope for far larger trade deals in the works — notably American deals with Europe and with Asia.

headline: In Missouri, Strapped to Mr. Trump
text: Being yoked to Donald Trump’s campaign has been harrowing for Republicans like Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri, the presumed early favorite now caught in a surprisingly tight race for re-election. “There you go again,” Mr. Blunt snapped recently at reporters who kept asking about his continuing endorsement of Mr. Trump despite the Republican nominee’s serial vulgarities and campaign gaffes. “Asked and answered like 10 times in the last week, and the answer’s still the same.”

headline: The Long Shadow of J. Edgar Hoover
text: Do the words “extremely careless” ring a bell?

headline: Peter Thiel Wants You to Take Trump Seriously, but Not Too Seriously

headline: How You Can Fight Donald Trump Right Now
text: One day, Americans who were too young to have followed the 2016 campaign will look back and try to make sense of it. They will want to know how such a dangerous person could have gotten so close to the presidency — a man who spoke of abandoning our allies, admiring foreign despots, weakening constitutional rights, and serially molesting women.

headline: Read Buber, Not the Polls!
text: If America were a marriage we’d need therapy.

headline: No Saints for President
text: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. One week! One week from today, this campaign will finally end. And we can get on to the important business of contesting the election.

headline: Australia’s Lesson for a Thirsty California
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — On his first visit to Melbourne in 2009, Stanley Grant, a drought expert and professor of civil and environmental engineering at the University of California, Irvine, had a question for his taxi driver.

headline: Watches See a ‘Brexit’ Boom
text: LONDON — The effect on the value of the pound of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union has rarely been out of the headlines since the June 23 referendum. But while the markets panicked — an estimated $2 trillion was wiped off world markets the day after the vote — the decline of the currency has proved a boon for Britain’s luxury watch retailers.

headline: The ‘Female Gaze’ in Fashion Photography
text: Alessia Glaviano is the senior photo editor at Vogue Italia. She has started a fashion photography festival in Milan with Franca Sozzani, the editor in chief of Vogue Italia. The first PhotoVogue Festival will run from Nov. 22 through Nov. 26.

headline: How Economic Gobbledygook Divides Us
text: As a rule of thumb, texts aimed at a general audience must be written at a 10th-grade level or below. This is what mass media does, and it is also what many great writers do: Emily Brontë, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, Mark Twain and Ernest Hemingway all pass the 10th-grade test with ease. That they accomplish so much with simple tools is part of what makes them great writers.

headline: A Powerful Story of Cuban Exiles Has Classical Overtones

headline: How Do You Greet Your Friends and Family?
text: How do you and your friends say hello?

headline: The ‘Normalization’ of Trump, and What Comes After
text: Early this year, when a string of primary victories established Donald Trump as a viable presidential candidate and making sense of him became a matter of some national urgency, one of the more incisive assessments came from Newt Gingrich. At a closed-door meeting of the Republican State Leadership Committee in February, Gingrich argued that Trump was not a conservative but rather an “American nationalist” — one whose success suggested he had found “a formula worthy of study.” He noted how Trump seemed bent on not just vanquishing his rivals but on eviscerating them. “He’s the grizzly bear in the room,” Gingrich said. “He’s not normal.”

headline: New York Values: How Immigrants Made the City
text: CITY OF DREAMSThe 400-Year Epic History of Immigrant New YorkBy Tyler AnbinderIllustrated. 738 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $35.

headline: First the Trauma, Now the Grief and the Angst, for Britons in Brussels
text: BRUSSELS — A bereavement. A horrific accident. An emotional spasm. For once, the language coming from the glass and concrete buildings in Brussels is laden not with the dull acronyms of European Union jargon, but with angst.

headline: Trump’s Inconvenient Racial Truth
text: With the race for the presidency entering its last days, Donald J. Trump last Wednesday once again made his pitch to black America: a new deal aimed just at them. “I will be your greatest champion,” Trump said at a campaign rally in the battleground state of North Carolina. “I will never ever take the African-American community for granted. Never, ever.”

headline: ‘We Don’t Owe Anyone’: Egypt Jousts With Its Chief Benefactor, Saudi Arabia
text: CAIRO — In the tumultuous two years since President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt came to power, one ally has kept the Arab world’s most populous country from economic ruin: Saudi Arabia pumped more than $25 billion into the faltering Egyptian economy, dwarfing aid from the United States.

headline: The View From Two Sides of the Standing Rock Front Lines
text: CANNON BALL, N.D. — The prairie is seething. Work crews are plugging ahead on the 1,170-mile Dakota Access oil pipeline, inching closer and closer to a river crossing that activists view as a critical juncture in their monthslong fight against a $3.7 billion project that they say will threaten water supplies and that Native Americans say violates their right to sacred land.

headline: Why the Lone EpiPen Competitor Hasn’t Taken Off
text: As the list price of a pair of EpiPen devices soared to more than $600 this summer, people scurried to find alternatives, occasionally throwing caution to the wind. Some bought cheap syringes filled with epinephrine, the medication in EpiPens; others made homemade auto-injectors, following the steps in a popular YouTube video.

headline: Scary Dogs! Rigged Machines! Votes From the Grave! This Election, Paranoia Reigns
text: There was the myth of Trump supporters sending wild dogs to scare off black voters in Ohio. In Texas, some of the voting booths supposedly became possessed, switching ballots cast for Donald J. Trump to Hillary Clinton. And then there was the amateur genealogist said to be committing voter fraud by jotting down names found on gravestones.

headline: ‘How Much Suffering Can You Take?’
text: SPOTSYLVANIA, Va. — Crushed by exhaustion, you may dream of a competitor’s head morphing into a Pokémon-like demon — and then open your eyes and still see it. The next day, you will quit the race.

headline: In the Rubble of an Airstrike in Yemen
text: The fanciest reception hall in Sana was bombed by a Saudi-led airstrike on Oct. 8, killing more than 100 people who were paying their respects to a prominent family after the death of its patriarch.

headline: A Corrupt Judge. The Mob. Indian Casinos. The Latest Thriller From John Grisham.
text: THE WHISTLERBy John Grisham374 pp. Doubleday. $28.95.

headline: Introducing The Daily 360 From The New York Times
text: 360 videos offer a new way to experience the journalism of The New York Times. These immersive videos put you at the center of the scene, allowing you to look left, right, up, down and behind you.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Life Beyond Bars: One Man’s Journey From Prison to College
text: Around midnight on June 30, 1998, Juan Echevarria, a 23-year-old principal in a drug crew, ran into a crack dealer on a Harlem street corner. What ensued, he later told the police, was an argument over money. In those days, Mr. Echevarria would case New York City in a bulletproof vest, often armed with a handgun and sometimes cocaine and cash, overseeing dealers who sold on the streets and in the lobbies of Harlem and Brooklyn apartment buildings.

headline: New York Today: A City for Comedy
text: Updated, 9:46 a.m.

headline: In Israel, a New Passion for Palestinian Cuisine
text: “This can’t be it,” I told my husband, Hudy, as I steered our rental car past a fluorescent-lit gas station and through a traffic circle.

headline: Adventures in Upscale Brooklyn
text: On a hot September day in Brooklyn, I got off the G train at Metropolitan Avenue and walked through Williamsburg, a neighborhood so thoroughly celebrated it has become something of a cliché.

headline: Want the ‘Real’ Brooklyn? Go Cheap
text: Green-Wood cemetery seemed a natural place to spend a few hours in the midst of a hectic urban tour. I passed under its imposing Gothic Revival gates and began heading uphill on Battle Avenue, named after a Revolutionary War battle that took place across its nearly 500-acre grounds. The views of the surrounding area and New York Bay became impressive after just a few minutes of walking. After several days in Brooklyn, I was realizing not just how huge it was, but how flat — so even the smallest changes in altitude provided for some great panoramas. The highest natural point in Brooklyn, Battle Hill, stands (at a mere 220 feet) within the cemetery.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets and Trump, Time to Team Up, New Currency Frenzy
text: Let’s say Donald J. Trump were elected president. How would markets and the economy react?

headline: Halloween, Instagram Style
text: Last night Eleven from “Stranger Things” and the Snapchat deer filter may have dominated the Halloween streets, but at parties beforehand a number of celebrities went their own way. Following, our survey of the most creative costumes.

headline: Standard Chartered Faces Inquiry Into Hong Kong Stock Sale
text: LONDON — Standard Chartered, a bank that is based in London and has extensive activities in Asia, said on Tuesday that it was facing an inquiry by regulators into its underwriting of a stock sale in Hong Kong.

headline: Teaching Children the Real Names for Body Parts
text: A presidential election offers many “teachable moments”: a chance to explain democracy, the electoral process and even a certain amount of negative advertising and name-calling. But this may be the first time that a presidential election has called upon parents to discuss slang terms for genitals.

headline: Need to Pick an Insurance Plan? Start Here
text: President Obama once promised that the Obamacare exchanges would make buying insurance as easy as selecting a TV on Amazon. Just a few clicks, and you could comparison-shop and pick the plan that’s right for you.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 25-31, 2016
text: Update, Nov. 9: In order to reflect the results of Election 2016, this week’s quiz will publish by mid-morning on Nov. 9. Thank you for your patience.

headline: Mosul Is Breached by Iraqi Forces, Heralding a New, Complex Phase
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Facing Islamic State artillery, snipers and suicide attacks, Iraq’s elite counterterrorism forces breached Mosul’s city limits on Tuesday, officers said, the first time government forces have entered the city in more than two years.

headline: To Many in China, Bai Ling’s Role in Documentary Is a Step Too Far
text: BEIJING — Nearly 20 years after government officials barred Bai Ling from returning to China, the Chinese-born Hollywood actress has once again found herself at the tense intersection of entertainment and nationalism.

headline: A South Korean Man Adopted by Americans Prepares for Deportation
text: Adam Crapser was adopted from South Korea nearly four decades ago, but today he languishes in an immigration detention center in Washington State awaiting deportation because his American parents never filed citizenship paperwork for him.

headline: California Today: A New Target of Gun Control Advocates — Bullets
text: Good morning.

headline: Clinton’s Emails. Again
text: How is it that with seven days left until the election, we are consumed anew by emails, Hillary Clinton’s private server, the F.B.I. and an investigation that was supposed to be closed?

Gannett Abandons Effort to Buy the Newspaper Publisher Tronc
text: For a deal that took six months of battling back and forth, the message of its collapse was cursory.

headline: Philadelphia Transit Strike Strands Thousands
text: PHILADELPHIA — Transit workers here went on strike Tuesday, halting bus, trolley and subway service, and forcing hundreds of thousands of people onto packed commuter trains and roads to get to and from work or school.

headline: 6 People Killed in Baltimore Bus Crash
text: Six people were killed and 10 others were injured on Tuesday when a school bus and a transit bus collided in southwest Baltimore. No children were on the school bus at the time, the police said.

headline: Will.i.am Moves Wearables Off the Wrist With the Help of Kendall Jenner and Apple
text: Wearable technology is finally beginning to go beyond the wrist.

headline: A Toddler Dies as Her Mother Checks Her Phone, and China Wrings Its Hands
text: BEIJING — A video showing an S.U.V. running over a toddler while her mother appeared distracted by her phone has prompted hand-wringing on Chinese social media about the perils of overusing smartphones.

headline: In Greece, Property Is Debt
text: ATHENS — At law courts throughout Greece, people are lining up to file papers renouncing their inheritance. Not necessarily because some feckless uncle left them with a pile of debt at the end of his revels; they are turning their backs on what used to be a pillar of Greece’s economy and society: real estate. Growing personal debt, declining incomes and ever higher taxes as Greece’s depression grinds on have turned property and the dream of easy money into dread of a catastrophic burden.

headline: Why Does Education Translate to Less Support for Donald Trump?
text: It’s probably the biggest demographic story of this election: Hillary Clinton has made big gains with well-educated whites, particularly women. And Donald J. Trump has continued recent Republican gains in winning over less educated whites, particularly men. As Nate Cohn wrote in an article last month, education has replaced the culture wars as the defining electoral divide.

headline: How Waning Competition Deepens Labor’s Plight
text: The Communications Workers of America union has learned to appreciate corporate consolidation.

headline: The Patriots Are Going to Win the Super Bowl, Aren’t They?
text: With the N.F.L. season around the halfway mark, there are many good teams. But just about any way you choose to look at it, one of them towers over all the rest.

headline: Assad in Person: Confident, Friendly, No Regrets
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — The guns were silent atop Mount Qasioun and the lights on its slopes twinkled over Damascus as President Bashar al-Assad of Syria welcomed a group of Western visitors into his French-Ottoman palace on Monday night, presenting himself as a man firmly in control of his country.

headline: A Trek to the Heart of Haiti’s Cholera Epidemic
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Azam Ahmed, The Times’s bureau chief in Mexico, describes his journey to Rendel, Haiti.

headline: Powering Australia’s Economic Surge
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — If you were designing a nation from scratch, it would look something like Australia. A Eurasian people, boring politicians, and an economy that virtually runs itself.

headline: Pussy Riot’s Nadya: Trump ‘Should Be Disqualified’
text: “Make America Great Again,” a new music video by the Russian punk protest group Pussy Riot, imagines a future in which Donald Trump has won the presidential election.

headline: Using Microservices to Encode and Publish Videos at The New York Times
text: Video publishing at The Times is growingFor the past 10 years, the video publishing lifecycle at The New York Times has relied on vendors and in-house hardware solutions. With our growing investment in video journalism over the past couple of years, we’ve found ourselves producing more video content every month, along with supporting new initiatives such as 360-degree video and Virtual Reality. This growth has created the need to migrate to a video publishing platform that could adapt to, and keep up with, the fast pace that our newsroom demands and the continued evolution of our production process. Along with this, we needed a system that could continuously scale in both capacity and features while not compromising on either quality or reliability.

headline: College Is the Goal: Will These Teenagers Get There?
text: The Times is following three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college. Today, Zac and Nate talk about how their plans to take the ACT test fell apart, and an expert gives them some advice on how they can recover.​ We also catch up with TaTy, who dreams of becoming a doctor.

headline: Chappatte on the Email Investigation
text: The F.B.I. warning seal, updated for 2016.

headline: A New Collection of High-Gloss Furniture and Accessories
text: For a new line for James Lowther’s Lacquer Company, Ben Pentreath (owner of the London shop Pentreath & Hall and decorator to William and Kate) stays true to his reputation as someone who lovingly upends classic British design. A Georgian-style night-stand, for instance, is done in slick olive green with a shocking robin’s egg blue interior. Craftsmen at Lowther’s workshop painstakingly apply 15 layers of extracted tree sap to every piece, sanding between the coats to achieve an impeccable high-gloss finish. “Nothing compares to the depth and richness of real lacquer,” Lowther says, calling imitations “flaquer.”

headline: Brie Larson, Salma Hayek and Gwyneth Paltrow at Lacma’s Art & Film Gala
text: The gala, which raised $3.6 million, was hosted by Eva Chow and Leonardo DiCaprio, and honored Robert Irwin and Kathryn Bigelow.

headline: Brie Larson, Salma Hayek and Gwyneth Paltrow at Lacma’s Art & Film Gala
text: LOS ANGELES — Is fashion art? Designers and historians have long bickered over the question. But in this city, where designer labels often underwrite major museum fund-raisers, fashion is undisputedly one of art’s biggest patrons.

headline: Want Your Own Piece of Hamilton? Head to Sotheby’s
text: Having conquered Broadway, Alexander Hamilton will now be storming Sotheby’s. The auction house has announced that it will sell a trove of hundreds of manuscripts and letters long held by the Hamilton family — some of them previously unknown — at auction on Jan. 18.

headline: Daily Report: A $25 Billion Fiber Merger
text: Another day, another $25 billion technology merger — and further evidence of how fast the industry seems to be preparing for an even bigger networking future.

headline: Navigating the Path to College
text: How do you navigate a path to higher education? Anemona Hartocollis, a national education correspondent and the opinion columnist David Leonhardt, joined guidance counselors and students from Topeka High in Kansas for a chat about the challenges.

headline: In Retrial of Etan Patz Case, Renewed Focus on Suspect’s Multiple Confessions
text: He fell to his knees, with tears in his eyes, and confessed to his prayer group. He sat down the woman who would soon be his wife in her parents’ living room and confided in her. And at a religious retreat in rural New Jersey, after an elder prodded Pedro Hernandez to open up, the words soon came tumbling out.

headline: As U.S. Election Approaches Its Climax, Ask a Question
text: Since arriving in the United States from my base in Cairo three months ago, I’ve been traveling across America to try to make sense of this strange and deeply contentious presidential race. With the finish line in sight, what do you still want to know about the candidates, their multimillion-dollar tax dodges, rogue emails and explosive videotapes?

headline: Transfer Smartphone Photos to a Flash Drive
text: Q. I have an iPhone running iOS 10. How can I copy my photos to a pocket flash drive before deleting them to free up space on the phone?

text: Bryce Pinkham bundles up in the season’s best coats.

headline: Taking Out a Highway That Hemmed Rochester In
text: ROCHESTER — Almost 60 years ago, this upstate city finished digging a deep trench for a highway bypass, a lauded effort to help speed residents out of the central city and into its suburbs.

headline: Review: In ‘The Story of Cats’ on PBS, a Look at Evolutionary Masters
text: It may have been a mistake to watch “The Story of Cats” with my cat. I’m concerned about some of the ideas the program might have put into her head.

headline: Bundling Up in Style with Broadway’s Bryce Pinkham
text: The slow approach of frosty weather has given an extension to anyone who has yet to pick out a stylish winter coat, and the New York actor Bryce Pinkham is here to help. Now singing and dancing across the stage of Studio 54 as the star of “Holiday Inn: The New Irving Berlin Musical,” a festive show based on the 1942 movie that gave the world “White Christmas,” the Tony-nominated star tries out the season’s standout overcoats and winter jackets.

headline: What 9 Gallery Hoppers Wore on Their Chelsea Crawl
text: Like the first day of school and the return of black-tie galas, the Chelsea gallery crawl ushers in a new season in New York. On Saturday afternoons, well-heeled art collectors and smartly dressed culture seekers take their post-brunch strolls through blue-chip galleries like Hauser & Wirth, Gagosian and David Zwirner. Save the deal making for the workweek; Saturdays are for looking, at the art on the walls and the fashion on the streets.

headline: Drivers Descend on New Jersey Pumps for Final Hours of Cheap Gas
text: MAHWAH, N.J. — Stephanie Long roared into a service station in her red Mustang late on Monday, yanked a red lollipop from her mouth and told the attendant to top off the tank, fast. She was worried about the red ink in her budget.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Hulu and More in November
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to find the TV and movies that are worth your time. Our website can help you find what to watch according to your mood. To get our recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up for our twice-weekly newsletter here.

headline: Did van Gogh Cut Off His Ear Because His Brother Was Engaged?
text: AMSTERDAM — New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh’s psychotic break on Dec. 23, 1888, may have been set off by the news that his brother, Theo, had become engaged to be married.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Vote for Clinton’ in Spanish? Ask the Abuelas
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — When Ofelia Cañez’s relatives see her coming, they do almost anything they can to avoid her and her incessant reminders to vote. They dart out of the room. They pretend to be busy. “They close the door,” Ms. Cañez, a 65-year-old Arizona Democratic Party field organizer, said here recently, wearing a satisfied smile and a Hillary Clinton button the size of a tea saucer.

headline: Tunisia, Through the Eyes of Its Artists and Intellectuals
text: Believing in a hope that spans borders — cultural, historical and political.

headline: Le Coucou
text: A tribute to old-guard French dining at the chef Daniel Rose’s first New York restaurant.

headline: Le Coucou Pays Rich Homage to Old-School French Cuisine
text: New York City cannot compete with Los Angeles’s patchwork quilt of cuisines, Northern California’s sainted ingredients, New Orleans’s discerning and passionate diners. What sets New York’s restaurant culture apart is that it never quite shakes the past and has never fully severed its ties to Europe.

headline: Illustrated Interview | Anthony Bourdain
text: The intrepid travel host and chef hosted the CNN travel series, “Anthony Bourdain: Parts Unknown” for several seasons. He died at the age of 61. The Times interviewed him in 2016.

headline: U.S. Policy Prevents Women Who Are Raped By ISIS From Accessing Abortion
text: Eleven-year-old “Asima” was marked with scars from daily whippings and rapes following her first 20 days as an ISIS sex slave. When ISIS returned her for a few days to her grandmother, also in captivity, she wept and shook, unable to speak.

headline: Xi Jinping May be ‘Core Leader’ of China, but He’s Still Really Nervous
text: BEIJING — Even in a moment of triumph, China’s president, Xi Jinping, exudes anxiety.

headline: The Season’s Most Interesting Black Dresses
text: With architectural shapes and a variety of textures, the wardrobe classic gets an update for fall.

headline: David Chang Bets Big, Using Silicon Valley Money
text: David Chang’s food empire spans more than a dozen restaurants in three countries, nine dessert bars, two cocktail lounges, one publishing company and a prepared-foods business. He has won multiple James Beard Foundation Awards and a pair of Michelin stars. In his spare time he appears on television shows and cooking specials and writes for his magazine, Lucky Peach.

headline: Blockbuster Deals in a Race to Stay Ahead of the Competition
text: World-changing corporate transactions just seem to keep coming. It won’t last, however.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: $8.75 MILLION

headline: Hillary Clinton, Moving Past F.B.I. Review, Turns Focus to Attacks on Donald Trump
text: DADE CITY, Fla. — Hillary Clinton moved on Tuesday to return the nation’s focus to the character and behavior of Donald J. Trump, hoping to define the presidential race again as a referendum on her opponent after spending days in open conflict with the F.B.I.

headline: Three New Cookbooks, for Health’s Sake
text: This fall brings herbalists, nutrition experts and proponents of strange vegetables into the kitchen.

headline: Community Policing, as the N.Y.P.D. Chief Sees It
text: To the Editor:

headline: Behind 2016’s Turmoil, a Crisis of White Identity
text: Call it the crisis of whiteness.

headline: A Sweet Solution for the Whole Holiday Season
text: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — I spotted this orange Bundt cake with cranberries on an elaborate sweets table at a recent wedding here. The cake stood out amid other delicacies, like cookies, flan and cakes with dulce de leche filling, made by the bride’s friends, most of whom had come from Argentina to live in this cold climate.

headline: Orlando Gunman’s Wife Breaks Silence: ‘I Was Unaware’
text: WASHINGTON — Things finally seemed to be going better for Noor Salman and her husband, Omar Mateen. He had been accepted into a police training program and had showered her with jewelry to celebrate. He had given her permission to visit her family in California and handed her spending money for the trip. And he had stopped hitting her.

headline: Morocco Says Crushing of Vendor in Garbage Truck Was Homicide
text: MARRAKESH, Morocco — Moroccan officials on Tuesday called the death of a fish vendor who was crushed in a garbage truck an involuntary homicide, and said that 11 people would be brought before the courts as part of a criminal investigation.

headline: Charcoal’s New Mission: Cleaning Your Face
text: Oh, charcoal. Are you dirty? Clean? Both? Neither?

headline: How to Deal With Digital Distractions
text: I used to teach at the graduate school of information sciences at the University of California, Berkeley. I couldn’t believe how many students looked at ESPN.com or its ilk in class. We live in a world of screens, where digital distractions contend with our need to learn. Is multitasking a good idea?

headline: How Ancient Humans Reached Remote South Pacific Islands
text: Some 3,400 years ago, before the Iron Age or the rise of Ancient Greece, people on the Solomon Islands left their white sandy shores for the cerulean seas of the South Pacific. Their adventures brought humanity to the most remote reaches of Oceania, like the tropical islands of Hawaii, Tonga and Fiji.

headline: Iraqi Army Enters Mosul
text: Iraqi special forces made their way into Mosul’s city limits on Tuesday as part of a coalition bid to retake the city from Islamic State militants who have been accused of continued atrocities against civilians.

headline: An Ill-Lit City Hall Park
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Education of Poor Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Guest Worker Programs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The PG-13 Reporters Covering an R-Rated Election
text: A few weeks ago, Erik Weibel was at a Bernie Sanders rally for Hillary Clinton in Pennsylvania when he was accosted by a group of young supporters of Donald J. Trump. The boys surrounded him, jeering and chanting, “Trump! Trump! Trump!” One made a crude comment about Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Pakistani Opposition Leader, Imran Khan, Calls Off Protest
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — After days of police crackdowns on his supporters, Imran Khan, Pakistan’s opposition leader, on Tuesday called off his plan to shut down the Pakistani capital with street demonstrations, averting a potentially violent clash.

headline: Hulu Adds ESPN, ABC and Fox News to Streaming Service
text: Hulu’s new so-called skinny bundle is beginning to take shape.

headline: In Lily Collins’s Beauty Regimen, Rules Do Apply
text: In her latest film, “Rules Don’t Apply” (out on Nov. 23), Lily Collins, 27, plays an aspiring actress, but in real life her career is red-hot. Along with the film (and three more movies arriving in 2017), she has written a memoir titled “Unfiltered,” to be released in March. Raised mostly in Los Angeles, Ms. Collins spent summers in England, where her father, the musician Phil Collins, lives. Here, she shares her skin-care and beauty regimen.

headline: Pope Francis Says Ban on Female Priests Is Likely to Endure
text: The Roman Catholic Church’s teaching that women cannot be ordained as priests is likely to last forever, Pope Francis said on Tuesday as he flew back to Rome from Sweden.

headline: Wendy Whelan to Open the Joyce Theater’s Spring Season
text: “Some of a Thousand Words,” a suite of duets performed by the former New York City Ballet dancer Wendy Whelan and the choreographer Brian Brooks, will have its New York premiere in February at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Presidential Election: Ryan Voted for Trump; Jay Z to Join Clinton
text: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are making their closing arguments in the battleground states of Pennsylvania and Florida on Tuesday, courting undecided voters and trying to motivate their supporters with just one week to go until Election Day.

headline: In Exile From the Knicks, but Still at Home in Cleveland
text: CLEVELAND — Charles Oakley pushed his hands into his pockets and peered at the small photo of himself on the street sign that bore his name. The younger version of himself in the photo was vintage Oakley: the high-top fade, the furrowed brow, the familiar blue and orange of his Knicks jersey.

headline: Nearly 50 Years After Leaving, a Composer Returns to Cuba to Conduct Her Work
text: For the first time since she left for the United States nearly 50 years ago, the composer and conductor Tania León will perform in her native Cuba later this month, conducting the National Symphony Orchestra of Cuba in a program featuring one of her own works.

headline: Leuca, Andrew Carmellini’s Latest, Opens in Williamsburg
text: LEUCA Andrew Carmellini, the chef known for the Dutch and Locanda Verde, and his partners in NoHo Hospitality have established several spaces in the new William Vale Hotel in Brooklyn, and this is the main event. It’s Mr. Carmellini’s first trip to the south of Italy; he named the restaurant for a town in the Salento area of Puglia. Chickpea Pugliese with bottarga, black spaghetti with cuttlefish puttanesca, and Sicilian pistachio cake are some of the regional fare. The dining room is wood-paneled. And under the executive chef Anthony Ricco, a wood-burning oven and grill deliver a few pizzas, roasted cabbage with Caesar flavors, smoked beets, and lamb mixed grill with eggplant Calabrese. (Thursday): William Vale Hotel, 111 North 12th Street (Wythe Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-581-5900, leuca.com.

headline: Gannett’s Failed Bid for Tronc Underscores an Ailing Industry
text: Gannett ended its takeover bid for its rival Tronc and in the process put a new era for newspaper moguls into prominence.

headline: 5 Must-See Shows if You’re in New York This Month
text: With the Broadway season getting especially busy, we’re here to offer monthly help on what you should see in New York. Here, the New York Times theater critic Charles Isherwood offers a look at two adventurous new musicals soon to open and a revival he calls pretty much “perfect.” There’s more: a chance to see Sutton Foster kick up her heels, and a bold take on Shakespeare’s history plays.

headline: Donald Trump’s Taxes and Hillary Clinton’s Emails
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets’ Jeurys Familia Arrested in Domestic Violence Case
text: Jeurys Familia, the Mets’ All-Star closer, was arrested this week in Fort Lee, N.J., in connection with a domestic violence altercation, according to a complaint filed in the town’s municipal court. Major League Baseball said it was investigating the matter.

headline: In ‘The New Negroes,’ Unpacking the Politics Behind a Word
text: This year’s New York Comedy Festival is underway, and one of its shows wants to do more than simply provoke laughter. Specifically, “The New Negroes” and its hosts, Baron Vaughn and Open Mike Eagle, want to challenge ideas about what constitutes black entertainment and expand the discussion about black life in America.

headline: In Robocall, White Nationalist Accuses Utah’s Evan McMullin of Secretly Being Gay
text: A prominent white nationalist who supports Donald J. Trump has started a smear campaign against Evan McMullin, the independent candidate who is running close with Mr. Trump in Utah, with a robocall accusing him of secretly being a homosexual who supports open borders and amnesty.

headline: Review: Verdi’s Requiem, in All Its Theatricality and Resonance
text: The White Light Festival, the annual Lincoln Center affair devoted to spirituality, loosely defined, reached a climax on Sunday afternoon with a stirring performance of Verdi’s Requiem, which purveys spirituality, theatrically conceived.

headline: Hatched From Peanuts, the South’s Hot New Oil
text: PITTS, Ga. — There may be more improbable culinary trails than the one that leads from a red clay road here in the country’s most prolific peanut-growing state to Beyoncé’s plate at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles. But as zero-to-hero food tales go, this is a good one.

headline: A ‘High-End Hoarder’ Sells His Stuff
text: A sampling of memorabilia from Brett Ratner’s auction.

headline: Brett Ratner Is Selling His Stuff
text: A Richard Avedon portrait of Marilyn Monroe taken in New York in 1957. A newspaper front page made for the 1987 Coen brothers kidnapping caper “Raising Arizona,” complete with the headline “Where Is Nathan Jr.?” And a clapboard from the “X-Men” set.

headline: Chief Who Guided Herbalife Through Troubles Will Step Down
text: As the chief executive of Herbalife, Michael O. Johnson has weathered a number of prominent struggles, including a bruising battle with the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman and a settlement with government regulators over the nutritional supplement maker’s business practices.

headline: Move Over Bill Murray and Eddie Vedder! I’m a Cubbie
text: When I got to Chicago on Thursday, I felt disoriented.

headline: The Best New TV Shows and Movies on Netflix
text: ‘Paddington’ (Nov. 16)

headline: The Price of Certainty
text: There's more to what you believe than you think.

headline: The Price of Certainty
text: It’s alarming to see how polarized politics have become in the United States. The wider the gulf grows, the more people seem to be certain that the other side is wrong. Certainty can be a dangerous thing.

headline: Halloween Dress-Up for a Cause
text: Bette Midler hosts the Hulaween Bash, MoMA P.S.1 hosts “White House of Terror,” and the Harlem School of the Arts holds a masquerade ball.

headline: Clinton-Connected Consulting Firm Sues Republican Strategist Ed Rollins
text: Teneo, the corporate consulting firm with ties to the Clintons, filed papers to sue Ed Rollins, a veteran Republican strategist and chairman of a Donald J. Trump super PAC, for defamation and breach of contract over comments made about the firm in recent days.

headline: The Khizr Khan Voters
text: As this ghoulish, absurd spectacle of an election sputters to the finish line, we can confidently say there is one winner: American Muslims.

headline: Review: Marina Abramovic’s ‘Walk Through Walls,’ a Memoir of Masochism and Pretension
text: Marina Abramovic’s first major performance art piece was based on an old Russian drinking game. In front of an audience in 1973, she took a series of sharp knives and stabbed each as quickly as she could into the spaces between her fingers. (In the game, there is only one knife and you take a drink for each nick.) Blood went everywhere.

headline: What You Should Watch Tuesday Night
text: ‘30 for 30: Hit It Hard,’ 8 p.m., ESPN

headline: Review: ‘Hacksaw Ridge’ Has the Guts and the Glory. But Where’s the Gun?
text: Mel Gibson can be accused of many things, but subtlety is not one of them. Even at his worst — I mean as a filmmaker, not a political thinker — he consistently proves to be an able craftsman and a shrewd showman. “Hacksaw Ridge,” the first feature he has directed since “Apocalypto,” a decade ago, is a bluntly effective faith-and-flag war drama, the true story of a remarkable hero with a knot of moral tension at its center.

headline: Costumes for a Cause
text: Costumes aside, Halloween offered philanthropic causes a festive way to raise money and awareness. Bette Midler brought back her “Hocus Pocus” character to life for her annual Hulaween Bash on Oct. 28, which benefits the New York Restoration Project. MoMA P.S. 1 and Susanne Bartsch (center, in red cape) held its fifth annual Halloween party on Oct. 29. And the Harlem School of the Arts held a masquerade ball on Oct. 31 at the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Review: In ‘The Eagle Huntress,’ a Girl From Mongolia Soars
text: Aisholpan is a 13-year-old girl who lives in Mongolia, dividing her time between a boarding school and her nomadic family’s campsite. With the release of “The Eagle Huntress,” a thrilling new documentary directed by Otto Bell, she may well become something else: a pop-culture heroine with the power to inspire girls (and not only girls) everywhere. It would not be surprising on future Halloweens to spot a handful of Aisholpans, dressed in traditional fur-and-embroidery hunting gear, pigtails fastened with pink bows, amid the throngs of Elsas and Katnisses.

headline: Review: ‘Anastasia,’ a Grand Duchess or a Great Pretender?
text: LONDON — Royalty, revolution, madness, memory. These are the potentially explosive ingredients of the choreographer Kenneth MacMillan’s “Anastasia,” his 1971 full-length ballet currently being performed by the Royal Ballet here for the first time since 2004, and offering the enticing prospect of the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova making her debut in the title role.

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Call Me Son’ Considers Identity and Fluidity
text: Who are you? That question nags at Pierre (Naomi Nero), the brooding androgynous protagonist of Anna Muylaert’s “Don’t Call Me Son.” This Brazilian film’s title takes on a double meaning after Pierre discovers that Arcay (Dani Nefussi), the woman he presumed to be his biological mother, stole him from the hospital when he was a baby. That upsetting news arrives when the authorities burst into their shabby apartment, slap handcuffs on Arcay, then immediately subject her and Pierre to DNA tests.

headline: In Ukraine, Not Even the Top Banker Trusts the Banks
text: MOSCOW — Many of the lawmakers and officials responsible for inspiring public trust in Ukraine’s economic and banking institutions have little faith that their own wealth would be safe in the country’s banks, according to recently mandated financial disclosures.

headline: There Are Many Ways to Map Election Results. We’ve Tried Most of Them.
text: There’s not always one form that reveals every trend in the most contextually accurate and accessible way.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Mosul, Clinton, Pakistan: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: South Africa’s Rising Art Star Builds His New Stage in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — High above a gallery at the Art Institute of Chicago, balancing on a bright red ladder, Kemang Wa Lehulere worked intently on a school blackboard, his slashes of white chalk gradually cohering to reveal a rounded form. A video of a cigarette slowly burning played as male voices sang.

headline: Review: In ‘Sagittarius Ponderosa,’ New Self Confronts Old
text: Archer, the central character in the transgender playwright MJ Kaufman’s “Sagittarius Ponderosa,” used to be Angela. He still is, as far as his family knows, and he doesn’t tell them otherwise when he goes home to Oregon as his father is dying. At 29, he can’t quite work up the courage to explain to them who he really is.

headline: Clinton, Trump, Mosul: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Court Opinion in Airbnb Case
text: The ruling by Judge Christopher R. Cooper of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia in a case against Airbnb by Gregory Selden.

headline: Federal Judge Blocks Racial Discrimination Suit Against Airbnb
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb on Tuesday avoided a potential class-action lawsuit by customers who accused hosts of racial discrimination when a federal judge ruled that the company’s arbitration policy prohibited its users from suing.

headline: FilmStruck Streaming Service Places a Big Bet on Cinephiles
text: While the cable industry wonders how many of us will be willing to cut the cord and do without a traditional television package, its online rivals have moved on to a more timely question: How many cords — albeit invisible, cheaper cords — will we be willing to pay for at once?

headline: YouTube Agrees to Pay Royalties, Ending German Music Dispute
text: BERLIN — For years, YouTube users in Germany have searched for music videos on the online streaming service, only to be confronted with one of the most hated icons on the internet here: a small red TV-shaped symbol informing them they were unable to view the video.

headline: Obamas Have Fun With Trick-or-Treaters
text: President Obama danced to “Thriller” and sang “Purple Rain” to trick-or-treaters at the White House Halloween celebration.

headline: Asserting a Muslim Fashion Identity
text: Last week, quietly and without much fanfare, the 22nd global Vogue went live.

headline: David H. Brooks, 61, Dies Serving Time for Insider Trading
text: David H. Brooks, a former military contractor who was found guilty of insider trading and fraudulently enriching himself through company funds, died on Thursday in prison in Danbury, Conn. He was 61.

headline: What Does Modest Fashion Mean?
text: A Muslim, an Orthodox Jew and a religious Christian walked into a room, but it wasn’t a bar and this was no joke. On the contrary, representatives from each of the Abrahamic religions had gathered during fashion month at New York University for the Meeting Through Modesty fashion symposium to discuss something they take very seriously: modest style.

headline: Donald Trump’s Math Takes His Towers to Greater Heights
text: Of the many rivals Donald J. Trump has accumulated over four decades in business and, now, presidential politics, one of the earliest was a New York City skyscraper with the boldness to stand taller than his own.

headline: City Unveils Possible Routes for Streetcar in Brooklyn and Queens
text: As Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration moves forward on plans for a new streetcar line from Queens to Brooklyn, city officials on Tuesday unveiled the different routes they are considering for the project.

headline: Glaxo’s Fallout in China
text: After a whistle-blower working for one of the world’s biggest pharmaceutical companies began sending anonymous tips about fraud and corruption inside its operation in China, authorities there moved in. They arrested top executives and corporate detectives the company had hired to track down the whistle-blower. Here is how the events transpired.

headline: Drug Giant Faced a Reckoning as China Took Aim at Bribery
text: SHANGHAI — Peter Humphrey was in the bathroom of his Shanghai apartment when the police kicked the door off its hinges and knocked him to the ground. Nearly two dozen officers stormed his home. They confiscated files, laptops and hard drives related to his work as a corporate investigator.

headline: World Series: Here’s How the Chicago Cubs Won Game 6
text: Follow our live coverage of Game 7 here.

headline: College Football Playoff Ranking: Texas A&M Is a Surprise No. 4
text: The College Football Playoff selection committee inaugurated a month of debate Tuesday by releasing the initial rankings of its third season. Alabama, the defending national champion, held the top spot, followed by Clemson, Michigan and Texas A&M.

headline: Plays Coming Soon From a Movie Screen Near You
text: The recognizable brand of Hollywood movies has led to a parade of musical adaptations and, more recently, a surge of plays. Despite a poor track record — “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” and “Misery” were neither critical nor commercial hits — “Dead Poets Society” and “Terms of Endearment” are both onstage now, and more attempts are on the way. Even Quentin Tarantino has publicly mused about “The Hateful Eight” onstage. In the meantime, here’s a look at movies-turned-plays that are further along:

headline: For Jason Sudeikis, It’s Time to Seize the Stage in ‘Dead Poets Society’
text: Still soaking in the happy haze that surrounds you after you’ve welcomed a new life into the world, Jason Sudeikis was contemplating his expanding obligations as an adult.

headline: Infections, Not Antibiotics, May Be Tied to Childhood Obesity
text: Is the use of antibiotics in infancy tied to childhood obesity? Some studies suggest so, but a new analysis suggests the link may be with infections rather than antibiotics.

headline: As South Sudan Troops Killed and Raped, U.N. Forces Didn’t Stop Them
text: As South Sudanese troops entered the Terrain Hotel and began attacking the civilians — many of them Western aid workers — who had sought refuge inside, frantic pleas for help to United Nations peacekeepers stationed less than a mile away went unanswered.

headline: Wells Fargo to Pay $50 Million to Settle Home Appraisal Overcharges
text: In the latest hit to the battered bank, Wells Fargo has agreed to pay $50 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused the bank of overcharging hundreds of thousands of homeowners for appraisals ordered after the homeowners defaulted on their mortgage loans.

headline: Maurice Sendak’s Estate Is Awarded Most of a Book Collection
text: The estate of the author Maurice Sendak has emerged mostly victorious in a legal battle with the Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia, which had been the repository of thousands of his original drawings and parts of his book collection before his death in 2012. In a ruling in Connecticut probate court, a judge awarded the bulk of the disputed book collection to the Sendak estate, not to the museum.

headline: Jurors’ Questions Hint at Division in Trial on Lane Closings
text: NEWARK — Jurors deliberating the fate of two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey accused in a bizarre plot to close lanes at the George Washington Bridge sent back three questions on Tuesday hinting that they may be divided.

headline: Montreal Police Face a Storm of Criticism Over Surveillance of a Journalist
text: OTTAWA — Investigators looking into corruption within Montreal’s police force for almost six months focused their attention on one of Quebec’s most prominent journalists even though he had neither reported on the corruption case nor had any strong connection to it.

headline: Seeking a Bargain in a Bottle of Water
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Review: ‘Attorney Street,’ a Gothic Elegy for a Fleeing Here and Now
text: Edgar Oliver conducts the most extraordinary séances. In “Attorney Street,” his seriously haunting new performance piece at the Axis Theater Company, the phantoms summoned by this one-of-a-kind monologuist are both vivid and elusive, as such manifestations must be.

headline: 7 Men Accused in Sex-Trafficking Ring in U.S. and Mexico
text: Seven men have been indicted on sex trafficking charges in what federal officials said on Tuesday was an international organization that exploited adult and underage women for more than a decade in Mexico and the United States.

headline: Avoiding Taxes, Trump-Style
text: Donald Trump’s claim that he was smart for figuring out how not to pay federal income taxes was obnoxious when he said it, at least for the millions of Americans who pay their fair share. Now we learn that he was able to avoid some of those taxes decades ago with a tactic that is illegal now and was highly dubious even then.

headline: Behind Closed Doors, Measures to Reform City’s Campaign Laws Raise Concerns
text: Three years after the 2013 elections revealed serious flaws in New York City’s campaign finance laws, the City Council may finally be moving to fix some of the worst problems — but not without including a few changes that would benefit individual Council members.

headline: Fox Honors Ailing Director Who Makes All the Plays
text: You know Bill Webb by his work. He directs baseball broadcasts for Fox and Mets games for SNY, distilling live shots, graphics and replays into cohesive narratives with verve and urgency. He is perhaps the best baseball television director ever.

headline: Cosby Lawyers Want to Suppress Testimony About Quaaludes
text: Norristown, Pa — Lawyers for Bill Cosby argued Tuesday that deposition testimony he provided in a civil suit more than 10 years ago, including an acknowledgment that he gave women Quaaludes in an effort to have sex with them, should be suppressed in his criminal trial next year.

headline: A Union of Politics and News Ends With Both Contaminated
text: The decision by ABC News to hire George Stephanopoulos in 1996 tripped alarms throughout American journalism.

headline: Safer to Puff, E-Cigarettes Can’t Shake Their Reputation as a Menace
text: WASHINGTON — A decade after electronic cigarettes were introduced in the United States, use has flattened, sales have slowed and, this fall, NJoy, once one of the country’s biggest e-cigarette manufacturers, filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Black Turnout Soft in Early Voting, Boding Ill for Hillary Clinton
text: African-Americans are failing to vote at the robust levels they did four years ago in several states that could help decide the presidential election, creating a vexing problem for Hillary Clinton as she clings to a deteriorating lead over Donald J. Trump with Election Day just a week away.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I’m just a headline — the bad president, the bad guy, who is killing the good guys. You know this narrative. The real reason is toppling the government.”

headline: Indians’ Heavy Reliance on Bullpen Probably Won’t Resume in Regular Season
text: CLEVELAND — No pitcher in the majors has been more durable the last four seasons than Bryan Shaw of the Cleveland Indians. Shaw has pitched in 299 games, the most in the major leagues in that time, and led the Indians with 10 postseason appearances before Game 6 of the World Series against the Chicago Cubs on Tuesday.

headline: New Research Center to Explore Ethics of Artificial Intelligence
text: Carnegie Mellon University plans to announce on Wednesday that it will create a research center that focuses on the ethics of artificial intelligence.

headline: F.B.I.’s Email Disclosure Broke a Pattern Followed Even This Summer
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. and Justice Department faced a hard decision in two investigations this past summer that had the potential to rock the presidential election. The first case involved Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, and secretive business dealings in Ukraine. The second focused on Hillary Clinton’s relationships with donors to her family foundation.

headline: Can Turkey’s Democracy Survive President Erdogan?
text: What is unnerving in President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march to authoritarianism is how dismally familiar it is: the coup that becomes a pretext for a massive roundup of real and imagined enemies; the claims to be the one man who can withstand the onslaught of foreign foes; the invocation of purported historical slights; the silencing of the news media. The world has seen this before in other countries. The pattern is tried and true; the tough question is how to break it.

headline: Criminal Complaint in Jeurys Familia Case
text: Familia, the Mets’ top reliever, was arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., earlier this week.

headline: Natalie Babbitt, 84, Dies; Took On Immortality in ‘Tuck Everlasting’
text: Natalie Babbitt, a celebrated children’s author and illustrator whose ruminative novel “Tuck Everlasting,” about a family’s immortality, found a fervent readership and inspired two films and a Broadway musical, died on Monday at her home in Hamden, Conn. She was 84.

headline: John Hicks, Star Lineman at Ohio State and Top Rookie for the Giants, Dies at 65
text: John Hicks, a standout offensive lineman at Ohio State University who became a first-round draft pick and rookie of the year for the Giants in 1974 but whose professional career rapidly fizzled, died on Saturday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 65.

headline: Just Dandy
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I do love a riddle, and Andrew Kingsley provides us with a classic one today, one purported to have no answer but with an interesting literary history.

headline: With Win Over Barcelona, Manchester City Begins to Write Its Own History
text: MANCHESTER, England — It was not an end — Pep Guardiola was quite clear — but a start. The night Manchester City beat Barcelona, the night “the best team in the world” was swept aside by Sergio Agüero, Kevin De Bruyne and Ilkay Gundogan did not represent the end of Guardiola’s work.

headline: ‘Rabbit Lady’ Challenges Police in Brooklyn Cruelty Case
text: The detective took the stand to talk about the defendant and her rabbits. There were a large number of them — nearly 200, it turned out.

headline: Weakened by Scandal, South Korea’s President Picks New Premier
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea replaced the country’s prime minister, the No. 2 official in her government, on Wednesday as she struggled to regain some of the authority lost to a growing political scandal.

headline: After an Eternity, the Cubs and the Indians Will Have to Wait One More Day
text: CLEVELAND — The Chicago Cubs, who have endured 108 years without a championship, and the Cleveland Indians, who have waited a mere 68, are nothing if not patient.

headline: 37th World Series Game 7 Represents Rare Opportunity for Cubs or Indians
text: CLEVELAND — It was 71 degrees at game time — which was 7:10 p.m. back in Chicago — when Josh Tomlin threw a baseball with 108 stitches to Dexter Fowler. This was the start of Game 6 of the World Series on Tuesday, when the Chicago Cubs faced elimination against the Cleveland Indians.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Syria, Pope Francis: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘The Story of Cats’ and Marilyn Manson in ‘Salem’
text: “The Story of Cats,” a two-part “Nature” presentation, is hard to resist for pure visual beauty. Marilyn Manson joins the cast of “Salem” as a bloodthirsty barber. And Triumph the Insult Comic Dog tries to find humor in the final days of the presidential election.

headline: Report on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Narrows Search Area, if Not Mystery
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Extensive tracking of debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared more than two years ago in the southern Indian Ocean with 239 people onboard, has further narrowed the search area in a remote swath of ocean off the coast of Western Australia.

headline: Word + Quiz: maverick
Photographing Everyday Beauty From Above
text: Kacper Kowalski’s passion for paragliding led him to ditch an architectural career for one as a flying photographer chronicling stunning, everyday scenes in his native Poland.

headline: Indians Would Like to Forget Their Adventures in the Outfield
text: CLEVELAND — The Indians’ unraveling that eventually forced a decisive Game 7 against the Chicago Cubs began in the first inning on Tuesday at Progressive Field. Addison Russell lifted what appeared to be a harmless fly ball to the right side of the outfield for the final out of the inning. But given some of the adventures the Indians’ outfield has endured in this series, the play was anything but routine.

headline: Hillary’s Male Tormentors
text: Weiner or no Weiner, Hillary Clinton is likely to be our next president.

headline: How Health Care Hurts Your Paycheck
text: If there is a coherent theme to this year’s election, it is the growing economic frustration of working Americans. While trade has been the chief scapegoat, a major culprit has received much less attention: the rising cost of health insurance.

headline: An Election Is Not a Suicide Mission
text: On Jan. 22, 1973, the Supreme Court of the United States, by a 7-2 majority, discovered a sweeping constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy and struck down abortion laws across the country. Within five years, the number of abortions in America annually climbed above a million, where it would remain for 20 years.

headline: Donald Trump Voters, Just Hear Me Out
text: This is my last column until after the election, so I’d like to address the people least likely to read it: Donald Trump voters. Who knows? Maybe I’ll get lucky and a few of them will buy fish wrapped in this column, and they’ll accidentally peruse it! Desperate times call for desperate measures.

headline: What’s Wrong With Politics? Let’s Start With the Benches
text: It’s ironic, really. Citizens have never been more distrustful of government, yet to alter certain sacred spaces would be considered sacrilege. We wouldn’t dare tamper with the chambers of Capitol Hill, for example … but what if we did?

headline: A Judge Keeps His Eye on Police Spies
text: The New York Police Department has had a long history of trampling on the constitutional rights of law-abiding citizens engaged in political movements and other activities through illegal and suspicionless surveillance.

headline: The Secret Lives of Hotel Doormen
text: CHICAGO — If the entrance of a hotel is its own sort of stage, then few actors have commanded one quite like Gary Sykes, head doorman at the Thompson Chicago.

headline: Taking On Militants After Acquittals in an Armed Standoff
text: What effect will militia members' court victory have on future confrontations?

headline: Photographing Everyday Beauty From Above
text: For those of us who take our passions to the extreme, it can be difficult to find a middle ground. With the Polish photographer Kacper Kowalski, who began his career as an architect reaching for the skies above and now is a photographer who works in the sky shooting the ground below, the situation was literal. But Mr. Kowalski didn’t start flying to photograph — he photographed to fly, and he did so in order to fuel what he describes as an addiction.

headline: Across the Fence
text: This is an illustration that went with a recent Op-Ed essay in The Times.
