headline: Leïla Slimani Wins Prix Goncourt, France’s Top Literary Award
text: PARIS — Leïla Slimani, a French-Moroccan novelist, was awarded France’s top literary accolade, the Prix Goncourt, on Thursday for her book “Chanson Douce” (“Sweet Song”), a thriller that opens with the killing of two young children by their caretaker.

headline: Article 50: Reviewing the Road Map for ‘Brexit’
text: LONDON — Britain voted in June to leave the European Union. But the process truly began on March 29, when the government invoked a treaty provision — Article 50 — that set out the basics of a withdrawal.

headline: About Time
text: Test your knowledge of the science and philosophy of time.

headline: What ‘Locker-Room Talk’ Sounds Like in the Philippines
text: Machismo isn’t quite what it used to be. Backlash and hashtags now hold politicians accountable for their so-called locker-room talk in much of the world. Yet the Philippines remains a glaring example of how men use language and law to try to emasculate opponents and maintain power.

headline: Lead Plaintiff in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Had Advanced C.T.E.
text: BOSTON — The former running back Kevin Turner, one of the lead plaintiffs in the landmark N.F.L. settlement over concussions and brain trauma, had the most advanced form of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, researchers said Thursday.

headline: Google Rebuts Antitrust Claims in Europe
text: To many Europeans, Google represents Silicon Valley’s perceived stranglehold on the digital world. But on Thursday, the American search giant tried to portray itself as a stalwart of online competition as it responded to European antitrust charges that it had restricted consumers’ choices and hamstrung its competitors.

headline: Mark Leckey Captures the Exuberance of Pre-‘Brexit’ Britain
text: No one Pauline Kael knew voted for Richard M. Nixon, and no one I know voted for “Brexit.” I lived in London for a little over three years, and that catastrophic British referendum of June 23, and the political meltdown, legal uncertainty and racist violence it has unleashed, have obliterated a place I thought I knew, and left the British art world unmoored.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte Plays U.S. and China Off Each Other, in Echo of Cold War
text: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines traveled to Beijing recently, promising to announce his country’s “separation” from the United States and alarming the White House and his own defense secretary.

headline: For Beyoncé, an Unexpected Performance in an Unexpected Look
text: Beyoncé, an artist known for dominating R&B and pop charts, performed at the Country Music Awards in Nashville on Wednesday, causing a few of the genre’s fans to scratch their heads and all of her fans to go into the usual paroxysms of delight.

headline: More Than 200 Migrants Drown Off Libya Trying to Reach Europe
text: More people are dying while attempting to cross the Mediterranean from Libya to Europe: at least 239 drowned in two separate shipwrecks, the United Nations reported on Thursday.

headline: Growing Up Gay to a Glam Rock Soundtrack
text: In early 1976, I saw Freddie Mercury stage one of the greatest charades in rock history. He was appearing with his band Queen at the Beacon Theater at a pivotal time, just three months after the release of “Bohemian Rhapsody” but a season before the song entranced the pop mainstream.

headline: Donald Trump’s Income Isn’t Always What He Says It Is, Records Suggest
text: On the financial disclosure forms that Donald J. Trump has pointed to as proof of his tremendous success, no venture looks more gold-plated than his golf resort in Doral, Fla., where he reported revenues of $50 million in 2014. That figure accounted for the biggest share of what he described as his income for the year.

headline: Cubs Players React to Win
text: The Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year drought on Thursday when they won the World Series. The Cubs topped the Cleveland Indians, 8-7.

headline: Ebola Evolved Into Deadlier Enemy During the African Epidemic
text: The Ebola epidemic that tore through West Africa in 2014 claimed 11,310 lives, far more than any previous outbreak. A combination of factors contributed to its savagery, among them a mobile population, crumbling public health systems, official neglect and hazardous burial practices.

headline: The Best New Movies on Hulu
text: ‘Election’

headline: Elite Runners Ryan and Sara Hall Add Parenting to Their Workouts
text: When the elite distance runners Sara and Ryan Hall adopted four sisters from Ethiopia in October 2015, it was the start of a year of seismic changes for them.

headline: Lindsey Adelman on Sharing a Visual Language With Her Husband
text: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: Make Siri Hear You on a Mac Mini
text: Q. MacBooks and iMacs have built-in microphones, but how do you use Siri on a Mac Mini?

headline: In Russia, a Western Taste for High-End Auto Sales
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The automotive history of the former Soviet Bloc resonates with cars like the funky Lada, the futuristic Tatra, the clunky but lovable Trabant and the luxurious Volga. Then there was the tanklike Zil — always in black — that shuttled Nikita S. Khrushchev and Alexei N. Kosygin through Red Square.

headline: The History of Southern Africa, by Train
text: JUST A FEW HOURS INTO our train ride, we know the passengers in the cabins on either side of ours: On one side are two young Canadians on a monthslong, round-the-world backpacking trip. On the other are four middle-aged women on a trading expedition from their towns in Zambia to Dar es Salaam, where they’ll buy supplies for their shops, including clothes and spare parts for cars. They’re not waiting to get to Dar to get started: At every whistle-stop town along the way, vendors try to sell things through the window — often produce at prices far below those in the Tanzanian metropolis. So the women are stocking up on items they can sell for a profit when we arrive in a day or two: tomatoes, oranges, passion fruit, boiled peanuts and, just this morning, roasted caterpillars.

headline: Parks and Jubilations
text: The top galas of the past week were hosted by Fashion Group International, the Central Park Conservancy, Performa and Lincoln Center.

headline: Whose Life Should Your Car Save?
text: The widespread use of self-driving cars promises to bring substantial benefits to transportation efficiency, public safety and personal well-being. Car manufacturers are working to overcome the remaining technical challenges that stand in the way of this future. Our research, however, shows that there is also an important ethical dilemma that must be solved before people will be comfortable trusting their lives to these cars.

headline: The New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2016
text: Every year since 1952, the Book Review has convened an independent panel of judges to select the New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books. Judged purely on artistic merit, it’s the only annual award of its kind.

headline: Parks and Jubilations
text: The Fashion Group International held its annual Night of Stars gala on Oct. 27 at Cipriani Wall Street, where luminaries like Tommy and Dee Hilfiger were honored. The Central Park Conservancy autumn gala took place Oct. 27 under a clear tent at the park’s Naumburg Bandshell. Performa hosted its fall gala on Tuesday at the Altman Building and honored the curator, art critic and poet Okwui Enwezor. And Lincoln Center honored Laurie M. Tisch at its fall gala on Tuesday at the Jazz at Lincoln Center Frederick P. Rose Hall.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte’s Pledge to Stop Cursing Lands in the Gutter
text: HONG KONG — When President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines vowed last week to stop cursing, at God’s direct request, few people in the deeply Catholic country questioned his faith or the logistics of the apparently divine intervention.

headline: A Souvenir for Anthony Rizzo, a Gift for All Cubs Everywhere
text: CLEVELAND — Anthony Rizzo was 3 years old when his father, John, first knew he might be a baseball player.

headline: Donations to Religious Institutions Fall as Values Change
text: It used to be that many people gave to their particular house of worship to get a prominent pew or extra blessings. Or because their grandparents and parents had always attended that church or synagogue or mosque.

headline: If I Were President . . . of My Club, My Class, My College, My Country
text: We asked students what they would do if they were in charge, what their concerns and hopes for the future would be. Empathy and forgiveness — a plea for more — and climate change were recurring themes, as well as issues political and personal. Here are condensed selections. Add your own ideas in the comments section at the bottom of this page (student submissions will be highlighted). Photos and drawings that interpret the question can be submitted via email, to edlife@nytimes.com.

headline: Daily Report: A New Helper in the Virtual Assistant Race
text: Gadget geeks will get their chance to size up a new toy at the end of this week when Google brings out Home, its voice-activated smart speaker powered by a virtual assistant.

headline: Killing of Saudi Student Shakes Wisconsin College Town
text: For nearly a week, the police in Menomonie, Wis., have been at a loss to identify a suspect or a motive in the fatal beating of a Saudi Arabian college student outside a pizza restaurant. Now, the city is trying to change that by raising money for a reward. The tally so far? $20,000.

headline: Art Museums Are Looking for That Next Big Gift
text: Public museums, too tight on money these days to compete for major artworks in the marketplace, long for the collector’s gift of world-class art that can broaden their offerings and attract new audiences.

headline: Violet’s Bake Shoppe
text: The golden banh mi ratio lives at this storefront in Forest Hills, Queens.

headline: For Banh Mi, Violet’s Bake Shoppe Has the Math Down
text: Some argue that banh mi, the Vietnamese sandwich, lives and dies by its bread, a cloud in crisp armor, preferably made with a pinch of rice flour for extra spring and crackle.

headline: Cubs, Nerds and ‘True Baseball’
text: Here’s a question about last night’s exhilarating, stomach-churning, 10-inning seventh game of the World Series between the Cubs and Indians: Was it “true baseball”?

headline: It Was 74-17 at Halftime. Then the Score Got Out of Hand.
text: If you gambled on women’s college basketball on Wednesday night, and you had Bluefield State plus 128, you lost.

headline: The Philharmonic to Stream Young People’s Concerts
text: When the New York Philharmonic televised its Young People’s Concerts from 1958 through 1972, it introduced new generations to classical music. Now the orchestra is updating the program: It said Thursday that it was putting videos of Young People’s Concerts, and additional educational materials and interactive games, online for schools and families to stream for free.

headline: A Joyful World Series for a Weary Country
text: It was 10 innings that to both sides felt like 10 months or 10 generations, this midnight final contest between benighted Midwestern teams, each so deserving and so long denied.

headline: A Shortage of Oncologists
text: In the crucible of cancer treatment, the bonding of patients with physicians often makes the unendurable endurable. The difficulty of finding and then keeping the right oncologist can therefore be fraught. Yet this problem, not uncommon today, is on track to grow worse.

headline: A Healthy Dressing Recipe From L.A.’s Newest Feel-Good Cafe
text: Dietary dogma is so strong in Los Angeles that even Dodgers Stadium offers vegan and gluten-free options for fervent-but-sensitive gamegoers. And down the road at Honey Hi in Echo Park, Eastsiders are catching a new wave of nutrition. It’s not strictly vegetarian, vegan, paleo, raw, plant-based, ayurvedic or superfoodist. The restaurant’s guiding principle is what they call a radical inclusivity. But according to its co-owner Kacie Carter, a chef and nutritionist, Honey Hi isn’t a movement, it’s simply “a little cafe with delicious food that makes you feel good.”

headline: On the Trail: Wednesday November 2
text: Donald Trump held rallies in Florida and Hillary Clinton held a rally in Arizona, visited Las Vegas and made a surprise stop in Florida.

headline: Your Questions About the U.S. Election, Answered
text: Declan Walsh, who has been reporting on the U.S. presidential campaign as a foreign correspondent, is answering questions from readers as the election nears. Below, he responds to  readers interested in the tenor of the campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump; the practice of voters who split their ballot; and what states will ultimately decide the election.

headline: What Lady Gaga’s ‘Bad Romance’ and Other Earworm Songs Have in Common
text: You should stop reading this now. No really, just don’t. You’re still reading. O.K., you asked for it:

headline: 10 Books We Recommend This Week
text: Halloween may be over, but the world still feels very dark. This week, our critics and editors at the Book Review recommend 10 grim books for grim times.

headline: Why Washington Needs Wall Street
text: The latest round of drumbeating has begun to prevent anyone with a Wall Street background from filling the top economic positions in the next administration. Not only is that not right, it hurts the American people by preventing those who have the best understanding of how financial markets work from taking a much-needed role in policing and fixing them. It is a form of discrimination. The time has come for it to stop.

headline: A Photographer’s Homage to an Architect’s Modernist City
text: Martien Mulder’s “The City Beautiful” is an exploration of the quiet weight of the relationship between light and space in Le Corbusier-designed Chandigarh, India.

headline: Russian Sports Agent and U.S. Marathon Officials Under Federal Investigation
text: The Russian sports doping scandal has led United States law enforcement officials to an unlikely spot: Manhattan’s Upper West Side.

headline: 19 Countries, 43 States, 327 Cities: Mapping The Times’s Election Coverage
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Cost-Cutting Is Hindered by Rising Risks
text: The chief executive of Credit Suisse, Tidjane Thiam, recently described Europe’s banks as “uninvestable.” His bank’s third-quarter results make Credit Suisse look just as bad.

headline: Rebuilding After Hurricane Sandy
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Melania Trump, Solo in Pennsylvania, Tries to Smooth Husband’s Rough Edges
text: BERWYN, Pa. — Melania Trump made a rare appearance on the campaign trail in the battleground state of Pennsylvania on Thursday, seeking to soften her husband’s coarse image by proclaiming to voters that Donald J. Trump respects all Americans and promising that as president he would promote values of compassion and charity across the country.

headline: From Sliced Bread to Gas Prices, Obama Takes Stump Speech Off Script
text: MIAMI — President Obama is savoring what is likely to be the last intensive political campaign of his life, and his speeches have been running so long that 30 minutes were tacked onto his official schedule Thursday to compensate.

headline: Iraqis Fear ‘Bloodshed Will Continue’ After Mosul if Sectarian Tensions Aren’t Addressed
text: ERBIL, Iraq — As Iraq comes closer to ejecting the Islamic State from its last major stronghold in the country, the question is no longer whether it can succeed.

headline: The ’90s Designer Making a Big Comeback — All Over the Runways
text: Even during his heyday of the early- to mid-’90s, the French designer Jean Colonna was an insider name — but today, his style is all over the runways. In 1993, The Times dubbed him “the popularist of Drugstore Cowboy dressing”: a pithy acknowledgment of his aesthetic, which relied heavily on synthetic fabrics, especially pleather, machine-made lace and machine-sewn sequins, animal prints and brash color combinations of black with violet, hot pink or lipstick red. It looked trashy — it did then, and it does now.

headline: When It Comes to Success, Age Really Is Just a Number
text: The question hangs over the career of every ambitious soul: Is there still time to make a mark?

headline: Veterans and the Candidates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Egypt Floats Currency, Appeasing I.M.F. at Risk of Enraging Poor
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s central bank on Thursday said it would soon allow the country’s currency to trade freely, part of a broader effort to save a free-falling economy and combat an increasingly prevalent black market for American dollars.

headline: Saying No to Breast Reconstruction
text: To the Editor:

headline: America's Test Kitchen Lawsuit
text: Read the complaint filed in Suffolk County Superior Court in Massachusetts.

headline: Food Fight Heats Up as America’s Test Kitchen Sues a Founder
text: Christopher Kimball was dressed in a Victorian costume and heading out the door to trick-or-treat with young relatives Monday evening when he got word that one of the food media’s messiest divorces was about to get a lot messier.

headline: Kid-Wrangling 101
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Andy Newman, a metro reporter, shares what’s involved in helping a group of middle-school-age city kids produce the stories of their lives.

headline: My First Film Fest: A Mix of Dark Themes and Sunny Attitude
text: You wouldn’t expect someone who had just created a movie festival for children — especially one that began on Thursday with a sneak preview of DreamWorks Animation’s cheerful-looking “Trolls” — to heave a sigh and exclaim, “Oh, my God, so many dark films!” Yet that was how Florence Almozini, associate director of programming for the Film Society of Lincoln Center, recently characterized her latest venture.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Killing of Brooklyn Pizzeria Owner
text: In the days after the killing of an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, speculation grew: Could it have been the settling of a score, perhaps related to a long-simmering feud over a tomato sauce recipe?

headline: Review: Fold. Spindle. Mutate. Oh, It’s Gibney Dance.
text: Behind the scenes, Gina Gibney is a force in the New York dance world, presiding over two dance centers along lower Broadway. She’s long been a choreographer, too, and this year she celebrates the 25th anniversary of Gibney Dance. With that comes “Folding In,” her first work since 2013.

headline: Mosul, ‘Brexit,’ Donald Trump: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Diary of a New York City Marathon, Now With a Finishing Kick
text: In 2012, I set out to examine the atmosphere, history and landmarks along the New York City Marathon route, one mile per day, in the 26 days leading up to the race.

headline: Iggy Pop’s Life Drawing Class
text: The artist Jeremy Deller organized a live drawing class in which students from art schools around the city drew the music icon.

headline: Iggy Pop: Musician, Icon — and Now, Live Nude Model
text: Ever since James Newell Osterberg Jr. emerged from a Detroit trailer park and reinvented himself as the snarling, bleached-blond, Dionysian rock god Iggy Pop, he has been one of the most iconic figures in music. With his sinewy frame and defiant stare, Iggy’s image has been immortalized by the likes of photographer Mick Rock (on the cover of his band The Stooges’ third album, “Raw Power”) as well as the artists Peter Hujar and Gerard Malanga. “I knew him from the imagery before the music, actually,” recalls the Turner Prize-winning British artist Jeremy Deller. “Even in photos you can tell he has a presence and is clearly quite a character.” For Deller, it was Iggy’s baring of his torso and soul onstage that struck him: “He’s not stopped performing,” Deller says. “From the age of 20 to 69, it’s been a continuous piece of performance art and documentation of his body. It’s interesting to me for a man to parade his body so much, and parade it as it changes.”

headline: The Voter Fraud Lie We Can’t Shake
text: Early voting is underway, and according to Donald J. Trump, so is voter fraud. Almost daily, he proclaims that “large-scale voter fraud” is happening and that the election is “rigged.” Politicians across the spectrum have criticized this nonsense as divorced from reality, deleterious to our democracy and unprecedented in our elections.

headline: Connections to a Cause: The Millennial Way of Charity
text: WASHINGTON — It was an otherwise routine bus ride through the Costa Rican countryside several years ago that changed the way Chase Adam thought about what makes people give.

headline: ‘Luke Cage’ Made Him a Fashion Hero
text: Mike Colter plays the coolest superhero going these days, on the binge-worthy Netflix show “Luke Cage.” Mr. Colter, who grew up in St. Matthews, S.C., let us in on his favorite clothing, explained how his role as a Marvel character has changed his wardrobe, and revealed why he prefers boots with zippers.

headline: In a Bar in Chicago, the Real M.V.P.s of the Series Got It Done
text: CHICAGO — Fifth inning, Game 7 of the World Series, and the Chicago Cubs were comfortably ahead by four runs. What more auspicious moment could there be for an out-of-town visitor to sneak into a friendly bar full of happy fans who were watching their team coast to victory?

headline: The Virtual Splendor of Paris’s Glass House
text: Discovering the existence of the Maison de Verre in Paris can be a major aesthetic epiphany. When you see a photograph of this translucent structure in glass, steel and expanses of glass brick — completed in 1932 — the impression is of startling modernity, something very much of its time yet strikingly ahead of it, too, like Picasso’s “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” or Duchamp’s “The Large Glass.”

headline: Going Head to Head With Pierre Chareau
text: The spare simplicity of the introductory galleries of the Jewish Museum’s new exhibition on the interior designer Pierre Chareau — even the inventive moving silhouettes on scrims there — do not prepare you for the fully immersive virtual reality experiences in the show’s second-to-last gallery.

headline: Green-Wood Cemetery, Where Presidential Aspirants Enjoy an Afterlife
text: LET us now consider a particular presidential candidate who made a fortune in business and real estate, who reveled in being famous, who had never held elective office before and who urged his supporters to cancel their subscriptions to a newspaper that had called him an idiot.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
text: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the post-election prognosis, and other news. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: Unlocking the Secrets of Boxwood Miniatures
text: Dutch woodcarvers once sculpted slivers of boxwood into biblical scenes smaller than walnut shells, and for a few decades in the 1400s and 1500s, elite clients, including Henry VIII, vied to own the miniature works. Yet no one seems to have recorded much about the sculptors’ techniques or even their names. In notes from the 1630s about an antique boxwood sphere with portraits of martyred saints, a Dutch art collector lamented, “It is regrettable that the maker of this ingenious piece has not made himself known with any sign.”

headline: Echoes of an Exposition, and an Assassination
text: BUFFALO — THE Pan-American Exposition of 1901 was meant to celebrate America’s ingenuity and dominance over the Western Hemisphere — you know, when America was “great again.” Eight million people paid about 50 cents each to see buildings edged in light bulbs, sprawled across 350 acres at the suburban northern edge of this city. They also flocked to the nearby Niagara Falls to watch daredevils try to survive the rapids.

headline: Review: In ‘Trash Fire,’ a Familiar Formula Fails
text: “For as long as I can remember, I’ve been waiting for my parents to die, so I could commit suicide without feeling an overwhelming sense of guilt.” With this opening line, “Trash Fire” lets you know that its writer-director is committed to commanding your attention. And also that he has seen, and admires, “Goodfellas,” which begins with a similar phrase.

headline: Review: Dance Arrives From India. If Only It Could Stay Longer.
text: “You’ve been there?” friends said in envy after Wednesday’s Nrityagram Dance Ensemble performance in the Gerald W. Lynch Theater. Yes, I’ve seen Nrityagram in India, at its home village near Bangalore and in Chennai — and yet the New York audience is in no way shortchanged. These are among the world’s greatest dancers; on Wednesday they gave as complete and fulfilling a vision of their art as any I have seen anywhere.

headline: Megyn Kelly: By the Book
text: The Fox News anchor and author of “Settle for More” says “Bridget Jones’s Diary” reads “like my own journals from pretty much every phase of my life and made me laugh so hard I cried.”

headline: Review: ‘The Pickle Recipe’ Is a Sweet and Sour Caper
text: The pickles in “The Pickle Recipe” apparently have quite a kick. The movie, though, is pretty flavorless.

headline: Former Napa Valley Winemaker Arrested in Fraud Scheme
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Federal prosecutors have brought eight fraud charges against Jeffry James Hill, a former Napa Valley winemaker and vineyard manager who was accused of stealing grapes and deceiving customers about the source and type of grapes in the wines he sold.

headline: Young Adolescents as Likely to Die From Suicide as From Traffic Accidents
text: WASHINGTON — It is now just as likely for middle school students to die from suicide as from traffic accidents.

headline: There Are No Wrong Thanksgiving Wines
text: No sooner did last Thanksgiving end than here we are again, deciding what to serve, how to cook it and what to drink. It worked out pretty well in 2015, didn’t it?

headline: The New York Times to Offer Open Access on Web and Apps for the Election
text: The New York Times is inviting readers to take advantage of its reporting, analysis and commentary from the lead-up through the aftermath of the 2016 election. Readers will have unlimited access to NYTimes.com for 72 hours from 12:01 a.m. ET on Monday, November 7 until 11:59 p.m. ET on Wednesday, November 9.

headline: Delivering Fresh Attention to Josef Albers
text: Last year, abstracts by the German-born artist Josef Albers were selling for $150,000 to $250,000 at auction: not bad for a guy who died 40 years ago.

headline: 5 Twombly Sculptures to Join His Paintings at Philadelphia Museum
text: The Philadelphia Museum of Art is one of the nation’s pre-eminent destinations for the work of Cy Twombly, who died in 2011 and whose monumental Homeric painting cycle “Fifty Days at Iliam” has been on permanent display there since 1989. Now, a group of five important bronze sculptures by Twombly, which he considered to be related to the paintings, will enter the museum’s collection, gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.

headline: Rococo Bad Boy Rebels in ‘Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant’
text: Among the 18th century’s lesser-known declarations of independence was that of Jean-Honoré Fragonard, the Rococo artist who was a rising star of the French Academy system when he decided, rather abruptly, that he’d had enough of it. As we see in “Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant — Works From New York Collections” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this rebellion took place largely on paper, in sprightly strokes of red chalk and splashes of brown wash that were, in form and spirit, the opposite of the history paintings he had been trained to produce.

headline: The Paris Agreement on Climate Change Is Official. Now What?
text: PARIS — When the landmark Paris Agreement to address climate change officially goes into effect on Friday, the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe will be floodlit green to celebrate the occasion. Now comes the hard work: figuring out the details.

headline: Review: ‘The Prison in Twelve Landscapes’ Reveals the Invisible Tentacles of Mass Incarceration
text: In “The Prison in Twelve Landscapes,” a meditation on mass incarceration in the United States, the Canadian filmmaker Brett Story arranges a series of oblique, geographical vignettes into an unsettling mural of systemic damage.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 9
text: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: New York Area Has the Nation’s 3 Worst Airports, Study Says
text: Those who fly to or from New York are fully accustomed to long security lines, labyrinthine paths to the terminal, flight delays, cancellations and other unpleasant happenings, not to mention the arduous or expensive journey to the airport itself.

headline: Review: In ‘Rainbow Time,’ Big Brother’s Watching (and Lusting)
text: The engine of unpleasantness that drives “Rainbow Time” is a sex-crazed, 40-year-old virgin who answers to the nickname Shonzi (played by the writer and director, Linas Phillips). Denied sufficient oxygen at birth, Shonzi is developmentally delayed; he’s also a bully who’s not above using his mental status to guilt those around him into excusing his offensive behavior.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
text: Ludlow 38, MINI/Goethe-Institut Curatorial Residencies 38 Ludlow Street, near Hester Street, Lower East Side Through Nov. 13

headline: Review: ‘My Dead Boyfriend’ Shares a Life, After the Fact
text: “My Dead Boyfriend” desperately tries to look and sound like a quirky indie hit, but that’s not an achievable goal when you have an unlikable lead character indifferently rendered by a name star.

headline: Review: ‘We Are X’ Explores the Travails and Triumphs of a Rock Band
text: If “We Are X” proves anything, it’s that rock bands the world over can experience similar trials: acrimony and fatalities, but also, sometimes, glorious comebacks. This fascinating and assured documentary, directed by Stephen Kijak (“Stones in Exile”), tells the story of the group X Japan, a cultural institution in its native country, framed around the group’s 2014 reunion concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Review: It’s 1996, and Jack Reacher Is Playing Nice With Others
text: “Night School” is the 21st book in Lee Child’s Jack Reacher series, but who’s counting? Most of us can merely marvel at the continuing allure of Reacher, think “you’ve come a long way, baby” and leave it at that.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Nov. 3, 2016
text: The New York Times film critics review “Doctor Strange,” “Hacksaw Ridge” and “Loving.”

headline: Review: Tending the Tempest Within in ‘Peter and the Farm’
text: The irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer and focus of Tony Stone’s wondrous documentary portrait, “Peter and the Farm,” is a man who contains multitudes. With his snowy beard and imperious bearing, Peter Dunning, at his most eloquent, conveys the authority of a biblical prophet but without a religious platform. As he surveys the 187-acre farm he has tended for more than 35 years, he also suggests a latter-day Prospero ruefully aware that his powers are waning.

headline: ‘The Voter Suppression Trail’
text: Find out if your vote can survive the great, flawed adventure of American democracy.

headline: Lending a Hand (and Fingers, and Fingertips) to Myths
text: The man in the photograph at right is angled slightly to one side, his arm curved and his fingers — held together, sharply separated from the thumb — pointing down into what appears to be an upside-down fish. Above him floats a bee, and a snake curls languorously over a branch, appearing to watch his activities with interest.

headline: Review: In ‘Loving,’ They Loved. A Segregated Virginia Did Not Love Them Back.
text: There are few movies that speak to the American moment as movingly — and with as much idealism — as Jeff Nichols’s “Loving,” which revisits the era when blacks and whites were so profoundly segregated in this country that they couldn’t always wed. It’s a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, a married couple who were arrested in 1958 because he was white, she was not, and they lived in Virginia, a state that banned interracial unions. Virginia passed its first anti-miscegenation law in 1691, partly to prevent what it called “spurious issue,” or what most people just call children.

headline: Cubs, Clinton, Mosul: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: The ‘Trolls’ Embark on a High-Haired Rescue Mission
text: Exuberant, busy and sometimes funny, DreamWorks Animation’s “Trolls” is determined to amuse. You remember Trolls — not the rude lurkers online writing nasty remarks, but those little toys with round tummies, beatific expressions and abundant hair shooting upward. Here they’re players in a fairy-tale Cold War parable.

headline: The Joys and Pains of Shared Birthdays
text: My friend and I have the same birthday, so I know he remembers when it is. In our 20s, we exchanged gifts. But as we aged, he stopped acknowledging my birthday (and is generally less likely to pick up the phone to keep in touch). This hurts my feelings. Still, he was incredibly supportive when my dad died last year. And if I ever have an important issue to talk through, he will spend as much time with me as I could possibly ask. So I’m conflicted. And our shared birthday is coming up. What would you do?

headline: Review: ‘Dog Eat Dog’ Is a Pulpy Tale With Nasty, Bumbling Crooks
text: Despite its slim running time — barely over an hour and a half — “Dog Eat Dog” somehow feels like six different movies. The first one, which depicts an especially appalling double murder through the speedy, sickly colorful perspective of an extended drug binge, is probably the least effective of the batch. But it lets you know that the filmmakers are not coming at you from a benevolent place, and that impression never lets up.

headline: A Blast from Campaigns Past ... A Grab Bag of Vintage Swag
text: IN an age of social media, it is easy to forget about old-fashioned presidential campaign memorabilia: posters, fliers, advertisements. The New-York Historical Society has not forgotten. Its exhibition of memorabilia from four presidential campaigns includes items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.

headline: Review: ‘Ivory. A Crime Story,’ or the Plight of African Elephants
text: The animals seem more humane than people in “Ivory. A Crime Story.” This roughly constructed yet passionate documentary isn’t shy about showing the massacre of elephants or about calling out the groups implicit in the killings. That bluntness and courage usually overrides the uneven filmmaking.

headline: Review: ‘The Ivory Game’ Follows the Fight to Protect Elephants
text: After learning that a beloved wild elephant has been slaughtered by poachers, Craig Millar, a conservationist, wonders aloud “how we got to this stage, as a human race, when we just lay waste to anything we value — anything we see just gets consumed.” Still, he vows to fight on. “I don’t know if it’s ever going to make a difference, and if we’re ever going to do enough, but we’ve got to try.”

headline: No Laptop, No Phone, No Desk: UBS Reinvents the Work Space
text: LONDON — A desk is like a home away from home for many in the working world.

headline: Election Day 2016: Teaching Ideas for Before and After the Votes Are Tallied
text: Updated, Nov. 15.

headline: In Chicago, the Cubs’ Win Brings Baseball Unity, for Now
text: CHICAGO — Margaret Pinkston, a 69-year-old housekeeper who lives on the South Side, was waiting for a friend to bring over her breakfast tray at the Valois Cafeteria on Thursday morning when she leaned in conspiratorially. “I’m going to be honest,” she said, lowering her voice. “I don’t know one person who wasn’t rooting for the Cubs.”

headline: 1976 | ‘Metropolitan Diary’ Opens Its Pages
text: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 28 through Nov. 1 with 1,561 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,333 said they were registered to vote.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll Finds Challenges for Next President
text: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump limp into Election Day locked in a tight race and saddled with voters’ unfavorable views of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll finds deep challenges awaiting the next president after a bruising election.

headline: How States Moved Toward Stricter Voter ID Laws
text: Voters in seven states will be required to show photo identification at the polls this year.

headline: A Narrower Majority for Republicans Could Widen the House Divide
text: WASHINGTON — The contest for control of the House of Representatives will probably yield an even more polarized chamber, leaving a smaller, more conservative Republican majority that may challenge the re-election of Paul D. Ryan as speaker and greet Hillary Clinton with a fresh round of investigations — whether she wins the White House or not.

text: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Retail Magic in the Meatpacking District
text: If you find yourself walking the Belgian-block streets of the meatpacking district, you are likely to be near a clothing boutique. It wasn’t always that way. Jeffrey Kalinsky, the founder of the high-end chain Jeffrey, was something of a retail pioneer when he opened the second location of his namesake store in the neighborhood in 1999. “Everyone thought it was radical,” he said.

headline: News of Charges in Price-Fixing Inquiry Sends Pharmaceuticals Tumbling
text: The generic drug industry was jolted on Thursday as shares of many major companies tumbled after a news report said that a federal inquiry into drug price-fixing was wider than previously believed and could lead to charges by the end of the year.

headline: Guards Were ‘Negligent’ in Fatal Encounter With New York Inmate, Judge Rules
text: Officers at the Clinton Correctional Facility used excessive force when they dragged a handcuffed inmate face down through prison corridors and then, when he was near death, provided faulty medical care, a judge in a New York State Court of Claims has ruled.

headline: Beyoncé’s C.M.A. Awards Performance Becomes the Target of Backlash
text: On live television, Beyoncé’s improbable performance with the Dixie Chicks at the 50th annual Country Music Association Awards couldn’t have gone more smoothly. With a giant band and brass section, the pop star blew through an extra twangy version of “Daddy Lessons,” the southern-fried track from her latest album, “Lemonade,” even working in a section of the Dixie Chicks’ own “Long Time Gone” in the middle. The Nashville crowd was on its feet.

headline: E. Lee Hennessee, a Leading Woman in Hedge Funds, Dies at 64
text: E. Lee Hennessee, a pioneering woman in the male-dominated hedge fund industry and the creator of one of the first indexes to track its secretive transactions, was found dead on Oct. 29 at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 64.

headline: Parliament’s Power Over Brexit
text: Someday the British  court ruling on Brexit may be studied as a milestone in parliamentary democracy. For now, though, it throws Britain’s fateful move to part ways with the European Union into considerable disarray.

headline: Criminal Complaint in Shooting of Brooklyn Pizzeria Owner
text: Andres Fernandez was arrested Thursday in connection with the fatal shooting of Louis Barbati, an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, on June 30.

headline: Walter Scott’s Character Scrutinized in Trial of Officer Who Killed Him
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The judge faced the jury on Thursday morning and spoke solemnly about “what many have called the greatest justice system ever created.” Then the murder trial of a member of the most visible arm of the justice system — a police officer — began in earnest.

headline: That Supreme Court Stonewall May Not Crumble Anytime Soon

headline: As Strollers Roll Through New York City Grit and Muck, an Industry Is Born
text: There is nothing more emblematic of New York City baby life than the beat-up stroller. In this walking city, strollers become homes on wheels, where babies and toddlers log long hours eating, napping and playing.

headline: An Old Hand Once Again Tries His Luck at an Around-the-World Race
text: MARBLEHEAD, Mass. — When José Luis Ugarte, the oldest sailor to finish the Vendée Globe yacht race, finally arrived back on terra firma in 1993, he soberly pronounced the solo, round-the-world race “an inhuman event” that should be done no more than “once in a lifetime.”

text: Miriam Weinstein, the mother of the filmmakers Harvey and Bob Weinstein and an inspiration for the name of their first film company, Miramax, died on Wednesday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 90.

headline: Kay Starr, Hillbilly Singer With Crossover Appeal, Dies at 94
text: Kay Starr, the self-described hillbilly singer who crisscrossed jazz, country, pop, blues and rock ’n’ roll in the 1950s with hits like “Wheel of Fortune” and “Rock and Roll Waltz,” died on Thursday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: Sorting Through the Clinton Email Case and What the F.B.I.’s Options Are
text: WASHINGTON — A week ago, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, jolted the presidential race by sending a letter to Congress saying the bureau had discovered new emails that might be relevant to Hillary Clinton’s use of a private server. The disclosure set off widespread criticism of Mr. Comey and unleashed a hurricane of news about Mrs. Clinton’s family foundation, Russia and F.B.I. infighting. Let’s sort it all out.

headline: Time to Move the Standing Rock Pipeline
text: President Obama has pointed a way out of a dangerous standoff over an oil pipeline being built in North Dakota. He told an interviewer on Tuesday that the Army Corps of Engineers was looking for a new pipeline route, presumably away from the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, whose members and allies have been protesting the project for months, saying it threatens the tribe’s sacred lands and water supply.

headline: Around Town for Nov. 4-10
text: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: At Trader Joe’s, Good Cheer May Hide Complaints
text: To explain their infatuation with Trader Joe’s, fans of the offbeat grocery chain typically cite three factors: low prices, an appealing selection of high-end products and, perhaps above all, irrepressibly friendly employees.

headline: Donald Trump’s Impeachment Threat
text: Donald Trump and other embattled Republican candidates are resorting to a particularly bizarre and dangerous tactic in the closing days of the campaign — warning that they may well seek to impeach Hillary Clinton if she wins, or, short of that, tie her up with endless investigations and other delaying tactics.

headline: Penn State Faces Record Fine in Sandusky-Related Case
text: Four years after Jerry Sandusky, a former Penn State assistant football coach, was convicted of sexually abusing 10 young boys, the federal government is seeking to fine the university nearly $2.4 million for failing to alert the public about Mr. Sandusky’s conduct and other campus dangers.

headline: C. E. Morgan Among Winners of $50,000 Kirkus Book Prizes
text: C.E. Morgan, Susan Faludi and Jason Reynolds were honored on Thursday at the third annual Kirkus Prizes ceremony in Austin, Tex. Each prize comes with an award of $50,000.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Donors Are Avoiding Democrats in State Senate Races
text: Two years ago, Alex Lodde, a Texas transportation magnate, made his first political donation in New York a meaningful one: He gave $100,000 to a small county political committee in the Hudson Valley to support an all-out effort by Mayor Bill de Blasio to deliver control of the State Senate to his fellow Democrats.

headline: Harvard Cancels Rest of Men’s Soccer Season Over Lewd Ratings of Female Players
text: Harvard announced on Thursday that it was canceling the rest of the season for its men’s soccer team after university officials uncovered what they described as a widespread practice of the team’s players rating the school’s female players in sexually explicit terms.

headline: You Might Be Paying Too Much for Your Chicken
text: Beef prices at grocery stores are lower. So, too, are pork prices. But chicken? Steady as she goes.

headline: Longtime Prospect Park Carousel Operator to Stop Making His Rounds
text: For the past 26 years, when children have raced through the doors of the carousel at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, Lucio Schiavone has gently called out, “Tickets, tickets please.” Once they have all settled, he rings a brass bell, presses his palm against a big red button and then perches himself on a tall stool to watch.

headline: Seeing the New York City Marathon From the Other Side of the Starting Line
text: On Sunday, Mary Wittenberg, the former president of New York Road Runners, will tour New York City’s five boroughs on foot — one of about 50,000 entrants in the New York City Marathon, a race she directed for 10 years but has never run. Wittenberg, 54, is a longtime resident of the Upper East Side, where she lives with her husband and two sons. Since taking over Virgin Sport, a company started by Richard Branson, in 2015, she has learned to merge training trips with work trips. A onetime competitive marathoner, Wittenberg spoke about preparing once again for the other side of the starting line.

headline: Much Is on the Line for California Chrome at the Breeders’ Cup
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — There is no racetrack on earth with a backside kitchen as chic as Clocker’s Corner at Santa Anita Park. This open-air bistro beneath the rouge-tipped San Gabriel Mountains is where the toned and the tan bask each morning in eternal sunshine as tens of millions of dollars of horse flesh circles the oval before them.

headline: ‘Cowardly’ Killings of Officers Strike a Raw Nerve in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — For law enforcement officers here, it feels like a still-raw wound being torn open anew. Less than eight months after a drunken driver killed two police officers in a fiery crash, two other officers were shot to death in separate episodes on Wednesday.

headline: Cubs Clinched Title Before Baseball’s Largest TV Audience in Decades
text: After Games 5 and 6 of this year’s World Series were seen by about 23 million viewers each, many began to wonder: How many more people would watch the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians play Game 7 on Wednesday night?

headline: Clinton Pushes Minority Turnout as Trump Tries to Rally His Base
text: Saturating swing states with powerful campaign surrogates and mobilizing a vast field organization, Hillary Clinton on Thursday intensified her public attacks on Donald J. Trump as a threat to minorities in the hope of driving them to the polls in decisive numbers.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This is why I came here: to break the goat or the black cat or God knows what somebody else wants to talk about. It’s over.”

headline: As Trump Ally, Rudy Giuliani Boasts of Ties to F.B.I.
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, seemed in a giddy mood when he was interviewed last week on the “Fox & Friends” morning television show.

headline: San Francisco Files Lawsuit Against Sinking Millennium Tower
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, when Frank Jernigan, a retired Google software engineer, and his husband bought a 50th-floor apartment in downtown San Francisco for $4 million, they felt on top of the world. And judging by the commanding view of San Francisco Bay from the plate glass windows of their living room, they were.

headline: Well, Señor Kaine, Hablaste Español Muy Bien
text: PHOENIX — “No hablo español perfectamente,” Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia told an audience of 150 guests here on Thursday, during a political event billed as historic by the Hillary Clinton campaign. For the first time, a candidate on a United States presidential ticket delivered a speech entirely in Spanish, a language that is a synonym for immigration in this state.

headline: Something No One Can Sing
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Ah, our young constructors ... they grow up so quickly, don’t they?

headline: Review: The Jobs Are Gone in ‘Sweat.’ So Are People’s Hopes.
text: In Lynn Nottage’s scorching play “Sweat,” the bonds among a group of working-class friends and family are frayed to the breaking point by the pressure of an eroding economic future. Keenly observed and often surprisingly funny — but ultimately heartbreaking — the work traces the roots of a tragedy with both forensic psychological detail and embracing compassion. Ms. Nottage, a Pulitzer Prize winner for “Ruined,” is writing at the peak of her powers, and the superb cast and the director, Kate Whoriskey, rise to the occasion.

headline: Missing South Carolina Woman Found in Metal Container
text: A South Carolina woman who was reported missing with her boyfriend in August was found alive on Thursday in a metal storage container on a remote 100-acre property and a registered sex offender was arrested in connection with her disappearance, according to officials and news media accounts.

headline: Turkey Detains Leaders of Kurdish Opposition Party
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish police detained the two co-leaders of Turkey’s main Kurdish opposition party and several of its lawmakers on Friday during early-morning raids as part of a counterterrorism investigation, the state news media reported.

headline: Oilers Equal Rangers’ Speed but Can’t Match Their Stamina
text: Cam Talbot, the Edmonton Oilers’ goaltender, stayed down on one knee for a while, stunned after Rick Nash had scored what proved to be the winning goal for the Rangers with 1 minute 21 seconds left in the third period on Thursday night.

headline: 12 Indelible Images From the 2016 Campaign
text: Photographers have shot tens of thousands of images for The New York Times and logged hundreds of thousands of miles on the presidential campaign trail since early 2015. Here are 12 of their most memorable photographs.

headline: South Korean Leader Says She Will Submit to Scandal Inquiry
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye said Friday that she was willing to submit to questioning by prosecutors investigating a scandal that has engulfed her administration, saying she would sever ties with an old friend accused of using their relationship to extort money from businesses.

headline: On the Trail: Thursday, Nov. 3
text: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton both held rallies in North Carolina.

text: Manchester United’s attacking problems continued Thursday in the club’s 2-1 loss to host Fenerbahce in the Europa League, leaving it at risk of a group-stage exit.

The Week in Pictures: Nov. 4, 2016

headline: The Post-Truth Presidency
text: We can say with absolute certainty that the Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year spell of futility and won the World Series. The Curse of the Billy Goat is dead. We also know with absolute certainty that on the dawn following the last out, the sun rose over Chicago, my dad’s hometown, at 7:26 a.m.

headline: The Banality of Change
text: A few weeks ago I met a guy in Idaho who was absolutely certain that Donald Trump would win this election. He was wearing tattered, soiled overalls, missing a bunch of teeth and was unnaturally skinny. He was probably about 50, but his haggard face looked 70. He was getting by aimlessly as a handyman.

headline: Who Broke Politics?
text: As far as anyone can tell, Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House — and the leader of what’s left of the Republican establishment — isn’t racist or authoritarian. He is, however, doing all he can to make a racist authoritarian the most powerful man in the world. Why? Because then he could privatize Medicare and slash taxes on the wealthy.

headline: Dalai Lama: Behind Our Anxiety, the Fear of Being Unneeded
text: In many ways, there has never been a better time to be alive. Violence plagues some corners of the world, and too many still live under the grip of tyrannical regimes. And although all the world’s major faiths teach love, compassion and tolerance, unthinkable violence is being perpetrated in the name of religion.

headline: Gary Johnson, Queen Maker
text: With just a few days before Election Day and all eyes fixed on the two leading candidates, it’s easy to overlook a remarkable fact: The Libertarian candidate for president, Gary Johnson, may tilt the election for Hillary Clinton. And if he does, it wouldn’t be the first time — not even close. The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.

headline: Are Voting Booth Selfies Fun or Dangerous?
text: By now you’ve heard about Justin Timberlake’s photograph at his polling station. Was he wrong to snap the pic?

headline: Suket Dhir, Men’s Wear Designer, From Delhi to the World
text: NEW DELHI — In a stifling office on the second floor of an anonymous building along a dusty lane in Lado Sarai — the new hub for young artists in a corner of the southwestern part of this capital city — a 38-year-old men’s wear designer Vogue.com has called a “global fashion superstar in the making” sat in semidarkness.

headline: ‘Jungle’ on Fire: Migrant Camp Destroyed
text: French authorities demolished the sprawling camp in Calais, France, last week, and hundreds of migrants are now camping out in tents in Paris. Step inside “the Jungle” as it was razed and burned.

headline: Questions for: ‘How the Internet Is Loosening Our Grip on the Truth’
text: Article: How the internet Is Loosening Our Grip on the Truth

text: A recent article in the Real Estate section revealed some of “New York’s Secret Doors and Hidden Rooms,” one of which is picture here.

headline: The 10.23.16 Issue
text: RE: THE PLAYBORHOOD

headline: Has a Teacher Ever Changed Your Mind-Set?
text: Sometimes we develop ideas about ourselves as a student that are at best, unhelpful, and at worst, destructive. For example, we may think we’re just not good at a subject, like math. Or we may assume, no matter how hard we try, that we’ll fail anyway. Some studies show that teachers can have a lasting impact on students’ academic futures by changing their mind-sets.

headline: My U-Turn From Isolation to Intimacy
text: There is a moment when your child gets too adolescent to cuddle. For me, that moment arrived when my 14-year-old son, Joe, headed to theater camp for a month. He was so eager to get there, he asked me to drop him off at the entrance. But there are papers that need signing when you entrust your child to strangers. Nonetheless, I was hoping for a goodbye hug.

headline: Using Airbnb to Sample Someone Else’s Style
text: Shirley Criddle and her husband, Markus Flatscher, are 20th-century design enthusiasts. Their Chicago home is filled with vintage furniture by the likes of Oscar Niemeyer and Paul McCobb, and Mr. Flatscher idolizes Frank Lloyd Wright, whom he considers one of the greatest architects of all time.

headline: An American in a Strange Land
text: I heard it often, traveling around Europe as a journalist. I even heard it from an immigration officer at Gatwick Airport outside London, who teased me as he looked at my passport. I was an American abroad, which meant being held accountable for the strange and fevered state of my homeland, which meant facing some version of the question “What is going on in the United States?” Sometimes the query had an air of schadenfreude, but just as often there was a hint of real concern. The rest of the world already seemed to be going off the rails. It couldn’t afford to have America follow.

headline: Where Did My Supermarket Go?
text: In New York City, distance is measured in blocks. The number of blocks a New Yorker has to trek lugging an armful of groceries could mean the difference between a great neighborhood and a crummy one.

headline: How to Busk
text: “I would recommend taking a weekend, if not a few, to walk around the area you want to perform in, to see what other street performers are doing,” Colin Huggins says. After taking in the competition, run your idea by a few friends. Huggins, who is 38 and played piano for the Joffrey Ballet School during its practices in New York, now plays a baby grand, which he pushes on a dolly over the streets of Greenwich Village. “Come up with something unique,” he says. “People who come to New York, they want to see something unique.”

headline: Presidential Election: Beyoncé and Jay Z Join Hillary Clinton
text: The final Friday of the 2016 election cycle follows days of musical and political celebrities campaigning on Hillary Clinton’s behalf, including a concert with Jay Z and Beyoncé on Friday in Cleveland.

headline: Beleaguered

headline: Last Economic Snapshot Before the Election Shows Healthy Job Growth
text: The last time the unemployment rate was running this low was in early 2008. But by Election Day that year, the economy was in sad shape and getting worse by every measure. Hundreds of thousands of jobs were vanishing, housing prices were plunging, paychecks were shrinking and credit was tight.

headline: Billboard, Souvenir, Metaphor: The Many Uses of a German Beer Coaster
text: Breweries provide them, waiters keep running tabs on them, tourists collect them, and this summer a local government repurposed them as political billboards to spread messages of tolerance.

headline: As Deer Chew Up Suburbs, Some Say a Good Fence Is the Best Defense
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Given her home’s location near the corner of Deertrack Lane and Whitetail Road, it should come as no surprise that Ellen Shapiro, an ardent gardener, had a serious deer problem.

headline: Afghanistan Itself Is Now Taking In the Most Afghan Migrants
text: SAMARKHEL, Afghanistan — There is one country in the world that is now taking in more Afghan migrants than all the countries in Europe and South Asia put together this year.

headline: A Militia Gets Battle Ready for a ‘Gun-Grabbing’ Clinton Presidency
text: JACKSON, Ga. — “Put the guns down!”

headline: Teaching With: ‘11 Excellent Reasons Not to Vote?’
text: Some 93 million eligible American citizens did not vote during the 2012 presidential election. How many tens of millions of people will choose not to vote in this year’s election? What might be their reasons?

headline: G.O.P. Secretary of State Fund-Raising and Ballot Initiative Project
text: In 2015, the Republican State Leadership Committee — which includes secretaries of state, who are charged with ensuring fair and accurate elections — began a program to defeat liberal ballot initiatives on topics like the minimum wage, and to raise money from corporations that also wanted to kill these efforts. Here is a look at the push.

headline: These Officials Help Write Ballot Questions. Companies Write Them Checks.
text: WASHINGTON — Big-money corporate lobbying has reached into one of the most obscure corners of state government: the offices of secretaries of state, the people charged with running elections impartially.

headline: Morning Agenda: Wells Fargo, Washington and Wall Street, Pharma Price-Fixing
text: They just keep coming. Wells Fargo, already reeling from a scandal over fake accounts and a settlement over home appraisal overcharges, has been hit with yet more accusations.

headline: A Venice Restaurant With Its Ethos Right in Its Name
text: There is no coyness to the ethos of Local, a modern new restaurant in Venice — it’s right there in the English-language name. Everything that Local serves originates nearby, or at least has a Venetian twist, including the chef, Matteo Tagliapietra, who is from the nearby island of Burano.

headline: Going to the Emergency Room Without Leaving the Living Room
text: For a while, paramedics were rushing Maria Vitale to the emergency room at Long Island Jewish Medical Center every few weeks.

headline: Whales Can Really Rock With Their Mellow Songs
text: When a whale sings, it fills the sea with more than just serene sounds. It also sends vibrations coursing through the water like a speaker with the bass turned way up.

text: Half of all voters in the nation live in a county that was won in a landslide.

headline: Together Again After a 14-Year Detour
text: For Marlena Baldacci and Ryan Militana, their first meeting as 16-year-olds at the Lewis School of Driving in New Canaan, would leave a lasting impression, leading them to marriage years later.

headline: The Walls in Our Heads
text: Even though Donald J. Trump took a brief break from stumping the other day to open a new Trump hotel, in Washington, D.C., he has rarely paused in nearly 18 months of political campaigning in selling the American electorate hard on his latest, most ambitious, mega-development: the Wall. As if lifted from a real estate brochure, the adjectives, stitched together, soothe and seduce: “An impenetrable, physical, tall, powerful, beautiful, southern” — the “southern” rather innocuously tucked in, like a house advertising “southern exposure” — “border wall.”

headline: How the First ‘Bad Santa’ Boozed Down the Chimney
text: When Bob Weinstein first received the script for “Bad Santa,” he felt that a gift had been dropped in his lap. Universal had set the project aside, and Mr. Weinstein snapped it up for his company at the time, Miramax: “I asked a Universal executive, ‘Why’d you guys pass on it?’ And he said, ‘It was the most foul, disgusting, misogynistic, anti-Christmas, anti-children thing we could imagine.’” Mr. Weinstein recalled. “That’s exactly why I bought it.”

headline: Vote, but Don’t Tell
text: The election is almost over, so let the healing begin. I’ll go first. To my brother, whom I will identify here only as Martin Wadler, I forgive you for posting those uninformed and inaccurate anti-Clinton screeds on Facebook, often on the page of my best friend, Herb, occasionally on mine. I should not have blocked you so frequently, though I would like to point out that you can only block someone frequently if you unblock them frequently, which I always did. Eventually.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Seeking Damages for Half Cups of Coffee
text: Ally writes: Every morning my girlfriend and I sit on the couch and drink coffee. Recently she started giving me half portions because she says I never finish mine. headline: Islamists March in Jakarta, Demanding Christian Governor Be Jailed

headline: Why’d You Do That? Parsing the Election Polling

headline: Launching a Start Up — Scholly — and Finding Scholarships
text: Christopher Gray’s first job title after graduation was C.E.O. As the son of a single mother who lost her job during the recession, he knew he would need considerable financial aid to pay for college. After seven strenuous months of searching for scholarships, dodging scams and writing (and recycling) essays on leadership and community service, he raised $1.3 million. Then, as a student at Drexel University in Philadelphia, he turned his experience into a social enterprise — an app called Scholly that matches students with a personalized list of scholarships. Scholly soared to No. 1 in the iOS App Store after Mr. Gray pitched it on “Shark Tank.” In three years, Scholly has been downloaded over a million times and has helped students raise more than $50 million.

headline: A Very Jonathan Adler Hotel
text: Next month, the ’50s-era Parker Palm Springs Hotel unveils a top-to-bottom renovation, plus a massive 7-foot-tall bronze banana soon to sit on the main lawn. The designer Jonathan Adler, whose wide-ranging lifestyle empire has made pottery, furniture, lighting and even handbags, says of his first public foray into sculpture, “I felt this urge to make something that was timeless, but also relevant and provocative in the age of Instagram.” (Indeed, the peels, which function as seating, seem ready for their social-media close-up.) But Adler could also be describing the rest of the hotel, which he’s updated in his inimitable cheeky and cheery fashion. Given the town’s increasing popularity, travelers have no shortage of hotel options, so he sought to make this one “the perfect fantasy of what a Palm Springs house should be.”

headline: 3 U.S. Military Trainers Killed at Jordan Air Base

headline: 1916: British Flotilla Frees Dutch Ship From Pirate Fleet
text: LONDON — A despatch from Amsterdam announces that the Batavier Line steamer Oldambt, which left Rotterdam for London on Wednesday evening, was stopped outside the Dutch territorial limit by a fleet of German torpedo boats and submarines. The Germans placed a crew on board the Oldambt for the purpose of taking the steamer into Zeebrugge, but before they could get under way a flotilla of British torpedo boats steamed up, whereupon the Germans took flight, having first placed bombs in the engine-room of the Oldambt.

headline: In Nicaragua, a Blatantly Rigged Election

headline: Why China Is Intervening in Hong Kong’s Legislature

headline: A Boy Raised by a Few ‘20th Century Women’
text: When the director Mike Mills was growing up in Santa Barbara, Calif., in the late 1970s, he and his mom would check the stock reports in the newspaper in the morning at the kitchen table. It was an odd but sacred ritual for the essentially single mother and her son, and it’s a scene that is replayed in Mr. Mills’s richly autobiographical new film, “20th Century Women.”

headline: Destroying an 11-Apartment Structure to Build a Mansion
text: For the past two years or so, my daily comings and goings have taken me past a building on my Brooklyn Heights block ripped down to the studs by a developer with the ambition of returning it to the market as a five-story brownstone for $18 million. Renovations are ubiquitous in Brooklyn — home improvement is as distinguishing an element here as surgically taut faces are on Park Avenue — but this project possessed a team of workmen so big it seemed as though a regional airport were under construction. Greeting the foreman, an Irishman with intense eyes who appeared to have landed in the world of HVAC from the world of James Joyce, became such an integral part of my morning habit that I would worry about him on the days he wasn’t out front, poring over blueprints on the hood of his car.

headline: Look It Up
text: John Simpson, whose memoir, “The Word Detective,” is reviewed this week, was 22 years old and a freshly minted master of medieval studies when he was hired by the Oxford English Dictionary, in 1976. Even though he didn’t know it at the time, he would soon learn that the O.E.D. — a “historical dictionary,” to distinguish it from its merely lexicographic brethren — hired “a lot of medievalists,” he said in a phone interview. “If you know the early stuff, you can look forward to what happens later.” What won’t get you hired by the O.E.D. are moony declarations of how much you “love words.” Such ardor, after all, might come at the expense of being able to treat words as objects for analysis. In “The Word Detective,” Simpson recalls he was also wary of inveterate typers (“We normally asked for handwritten letters”), poor spellers (of course) and those who claim to “enjoy” crossword puzzles. He reserved particular opprobrium for cover letters that included the job-application cliché “hone” (“I honed my lexicographic skills through a passionate love of words and my enjoyment of crossword puzzles”).

headline: Dreading a President Clinton or Trump? How to Try a New Country
text: Rob Calabrese, a Canadian radio disc jockey, launched a website earlier this year inviting Americans to take refuge on a Nova Scotia island. The site, Cape Breton if Donald Trump Wins, has received two million visits and so many inquiries about emigrating that it now offers a link to the Canadian government’s application. (President Obama even mentioned it during a state dinner with Justin Trudeau, the Canadian prime minister.) The site was, of course, a response to a familiar refrain, the threat to move abroad if politics doesn’t go your way. During this presidential campaign, people took to Twitter to vow to move to Canada, and the use of the search phrase “move to Canada” surged on Google.

headline: Searching for Lady Kung Fu

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
text: A Lesser Tribe: For a few years before he died of pancreatic cancer last March, the novelist Pat Conroy maintained a charmingly capricious blog on his website. Fans may recognize some of its contents in “A Lowcountry Heart,” a posthumous essay collection new at No. 11 in hardcover nonfiction, including a tribute to the writer Ann Patchett that takes the long way to its destination. Here’s a sample detour, about physical beauty in the publishing world: “Late in my time at Houghton Mifflin, two young women arrived on the scene who were the talk of the company — Susan Minot with a novel called ‘Monkeys’ and Ann Patchett with one called ‘The Patron Saint of Liars.’ Both were talented, all agreed, but both were also drop dead beautiful.

headline: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
text: Sooner or later, Harry Bosch will have to turn in his gun and retire from police work, but until that time Michael Connelly continues to think up creative ways to keep his old war horse on the job. In THE WRONG SIDE OF GOODBYE (Little, Brown, $29), Bosch is doing part-time volunteer work for the undermanned police force of San Fernando, an independent town completely surrounded by the city of Los Angeles. “Look at me,” he remarks, “scratching and fighting to keep a badge on my belt at my age.” The work isn’t too taxing, but in going through several years’ worth of reports on sexual assaults, he notes a pattern common to four of these unsolved cases, which can only mean that a serial rapist is on the loose. And despite a bland sobriquet (“the Screen Cutter”) that makes him sound like the village handyman, this predator is likely to become ever more violent.

headline: It’s All Smiles at Sorriso Italian Market in Queens
text: On a recent Sunday in Astoria, Queens, Sal DePaola looked out the windows of Sorriso Italian Salumeria, a box of a store with its walls nearly bursting with Italian foodstuffs. Gesturing toward the street, he lamented that some of the area’s residents seem set in their daily routines, too focused to even notice the humble storefront.

headline: Sculpture’s Woman of Steel, Carol Bove
text: A visit to the sculptor Carol Bove’s studio in a former brick factory near the Brooklyn waterfront does not exactly make Rimbaud’s advice for the true artist — to engage in a “boundless and systematized disorganization of all the senses” — leap to mind. A huge manufacturing floor dominated by an overhead gantry that looks as if it could hoist a subway car, the place instead evokes distinctly unpoetic phrases like “productivity gains” and “customer fulfillment strategies.”

headline: How Domenica Ramos, Marathon Runner, Spends Her Sundays
text: Domenica Ramos immigrated to New York City from Ecuador in 2001. In 2013, she started starting running to cope with the stress of single motherhood and quickly became a Boston Marathon qualifier, finishing her fourth marathon last month in Chicago with a time of 3 hours 24 minutes 12 seconds. A resident of Hamilton Heights in Manhattan, Ms. Ramos, 33, balances training with 12-hour waitressing shifts and caring for her 6-year-old daughter, Gabriela. She was hoping to finish the New York City Marathon in 3 hours 20 minutes. Recently, however, a mild injury flared up, threatening to slow Ms. Ramos down, but not stop her: “Deeply in my heart,” she said, “I want to line up at the start and run this marathon.”

headline: Recent Sales and Boldface Names
text: Another chapter has closed in the Bernard L. Madoff  saga, with the sale of the Upper East Side home of his younger son, Andrew H. Madoff, who with his older brother alerted federal agents to their father’s massive Ponzi scheme and who died from a rare form of cancer two years ago.

headline: Are Get-Out-the-Vote Efforts Targeting Latinos Working?
text: Turnout for early voting is up among Latino voters, compared with the 2012 election, in Florida and other swing states. That’s a relief for Hillary Clinton and her supporters. It’s also an opportunity for the small army of organizers, data analysts and researchers who try to better understand and refine the methods for getting people to the polls. Through Tuesday, they will field-test methods that could shape the demographic future of the major parties.

headline: Delhi Closes Over 1,800 Schools in Response to Dangerous Smog
text: NEW DELHI — For the first time ever, more than 1,800 public primary schools in India’s capital will close on Saturday to protect children from exposure to dangerous levels of air pollution, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
text: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

headline: Holiday Movie Release Schedule
text: All dates are subject to change.

headline: The Playlist: The Gospel According to Alicia Keys
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

headline: Philanthropy in Silicon Valley: Big Bets on Big Ideas
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The founders of Silicon Valley’s technology companies, many of whom have amassed huge fortunes at a young age, tend to look at their philanthropic giving much as they do their companies: They study a problem, explore a number of ways to attack it and eventually invest heavily to scale up the ideas they think will be winners.

headline: The Continuing Education of Patrick Vieira
text: PURCHASE, N.Y. — Patrick Vieira, once a master of angles on the soccer field, deflected a barrage of second-guesses as he stood on the sideline after practice Wednesday.

headline: Tales from the Trails: An Insider Look at the 2016 Presidential Campaign
text: From Marco Rubio’s “cute boots” to Donald J. Trump’s taxes, our reporters covered it all. Here’s a look at some of our favorite Times Insider stories from this unprecedented election.

headline: A Stranded $2 Trillion Overseas Stash Gets Closer to Coming Home
text: The next president may have a rare opportunity to close tax loopholes that have let American corporations stash more than $2 trillion in untaxed profits outside the United States.

headline: Rolling Stone Loses Defamation Case Over Rape Story
text: Rolling Stone magazine paid the legal price on Friday for its journalistic failings in a 2014 article about a supposed gang rape at the University of Virginia that it had already retracted in the face of widespread criticism.

headline: Daily Report: Vote Hacking
text: With just four days to go till Election Day, the polls for the presidential race have tightened. Democrats and Republicans alike are worried about the outcome.

headline: How Does the City Decide What Trees to Prune, and When?
text: Q. Many of the branches of the trees on my Upper West Side block have been cut, presumably for safety’s sake. Ditto my favorite Osage orange tree along the outer loop inside Central Park. Who decides which trees are a safety hazard? And who decides on the amount of cutting?

headline: Bites to Answer the Call of Guests’ Rumbling Stomachs
text: The doorbell rings, and they start to stream in. Hungry. Yes, there will be dinner, platters overflowing with the inevitable, and desserts galore.

headline: Touring Central Park With Frankie Legs
text: Despite a childhood accident that badly broke his legs, Frankie Legarreta now makes a living with them. The man called Frankie Legs takes customers around Central Park and New York City all day in his pedicab.

headline: Pedicab Driver’s Journey From Coma to Career as ‘Frankie Legs’
text: There are some who ride for their health, others who use Citi Bike for transportation, and more still who cycle for the soul. Then there are those who pedal for a living.

headline: London Has a Queen of the Night (From New Jersey)
text: LONDON — The New Jersey-born broadcaster, writer and comedian Amy Lamé has been appointed here to the splendid-sounding title of Night Czar. The position was created by the mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, who has promised to make the nighttime economy a priority.

headline: A Formula for Easier-to-Read Excel Work Sheets
text: Q. I have a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet on my PC and I want to make the lines of information alternate between gray and white for better legibility. How do I do that?

text: “Honey, I’m home,” Sarah Fearon said, stepping into a vacant apartment in an Upper West Side townhouse.

text: The New York Times would like to hear from women who plan to vote with different generations of women in their families.

headline: A Richard Meier Building. In Black.
