headline: Which Supplements, if Any, May Be Worth Your Money
text: Hardly a day goes by that people don’t tell me that one or more dietary supplement has cured or prevented an ailment of theirs or suggest that I try one to treat a problem of my own. And I am not immune to wishful thinking that an over-the-counter vitamin, mineral or herb may help to keep me healthy or relieve some distress without having to see a doctor.

headline: 6 Ways Pretend Investors Differ From the Real Ones

headline: Into the Dead Zone: A Sports Writer Heads for Obits
text: When Robert Eidelberg’s journalism class at John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens, convened in September, 1972, our first assignment was to write an obituary about ourselves. We were all about 15 years old, without much life experience (I was months from my first paying job at a supermarket), so the task was to invent our futures.

headline: France Detains 7, Saying It Has Thwarted a New Terrorist Attack
text: PARIS — Seven men who French authorities say were planning a terrorist attack have been arrested in France, the government announced on Monday, sounding an alert about the continuing threat from terrorism barely a year after the attacks that killed 130 people in and around Paris.

headline: Kanye West Cancels the Rest of His ‘Saint Pablo’ Tour
text: After two bizarre concerts last week during which Kanye West came out in support of President-elect Donald J. Trump and ended a set early after a fiery but discursive 17-minute monologue, the rapper has canceled the rest of his tour dates for 2016.

headline: Brazil’s Surfers Lament Demise of Amazon’s Mighty Waves

headline: Italy’s Last Bastion of Catalan Language Struggles to Keep It Alive

headline: Making Movies With Windows 10

headline: William Trevor, Writer Who Evoked the Struggles of Ordinary Life, Is Dead at 88
text: William Trevor, whose mournful, sometimes darkly funny short stories and novels about the small struggles of unremarkable people placed him in the company of masters like V. S. Pritchett, W. Somerset Maugham and Chekhov, died on Sunday in Somerset, England. He was 88.

headline: Jeff Koons Is Giving Sculpture to Paris to Remember Terror Victims
text: PARIS — Inspired by the Statue of Liberty, the American contemporary artist Jeff Koons is donating a monumental sculpture of a fistful of tulips to the City of Paris and the people of France to commemorate victims of the recent terrorist attacks here.

headline: Daily Report: At Apple, U.S. Jobs That Go Beyond Manufacturing
text: President-elect Donald J. Trump said during the campaign that he would push companies to bring manufacturing jobs back to the United States. He named one tech company in particular — Apple — which is the world’s largest public company and makes many of its gadgets overseas.

headline: ‘Hot and Unhappy in Unwise Shoes’: A William Trevor Sampler
text: “Each character is somebody that I know very well — as well as I know myself,” William Trevor once said. Here are excerpts from three of his short stories, originally published by the Bodley Head in Britain and Viking in the United States.

headline: Olympics History Rewritten: New Doping Tests Topple the Podium
text: After disclosures of an extensive, state-run doping program in Russia, sports officials have been retesting urine samples from the 2008 and 2012 Summer Olympics, in Beijing and London. Their findings have resulted in a top-to-bottom rewriting of Olympics history.

headline: Cooking Up Conversation as Martha’s Vineyard Quiets Down

headline: Three Big American Banks Pose Greater Systemic Risk, Regulator Says

headline: This Thanksgiving, Be Thankful for Science
text: Look, we’re not saying you can’t talk about politics at the Thanksgiving dinner table. But it’s been quite a November so far, following a seemingly never-ending campaign, and the anxiety in the air is thicker than your mom’s gravy. Some people are sitting out Thanksgiving with their loved ones altogether. Others are preparing themselves for acts of civil disagreement.

headline: As Obama’s Tour Ends, He Says U.S. Involvement Abroad Must Not
text: LIMA, Peru — President-elect Donald J. Trump, with his “America First” campaign slogan, sees an America that has for years been taken for granted by weaker nations and is too quick to intervene in intractable conflicts far away.

headline: Dinner and James Joyce in New Adaptation of ‘The Dead’
text: The centerpiece of “The Dead,” a novella by James Joyce, is a family dinner in 1904 to celebrate the Epiphany. At the Irish Repertory Theater’s staged adaptation, “The Dead, 1904,” presented with Dot Dot Productions, the audience joins in the meal. They mingle with the performers, including Kate Burton and Boyd Gaines, and are then seated for a multicourse feast during the performance. On the menu are beef tenderloin with fig sauce, honey-glazed ham, potatoes, bread pudding and drinks. It takes place at the American Irish Historical Society, a Victorian townhouse, and the meal is catered by Great Performances: “The Dead, 1904” by the Irish Repertory Theater, through Jan. 7 at  991 Fifth Avenue (East 80th Street); $300 including dinner, $500 for premium seating ($1,000 after Dec. 7), 212-727-2737, irishrep.org.

headline: A Tribe Called Quest’s Comeback Album Debuts at No. 1
text: A Tribe Called Quest’s comeback came at just the right time: Released the Friday after the election, the emotional and political “We Got It From Here … Thank You 4 Your Service” (Epic), the first album from the storied hip-hop group in nearly two decades, has topped the Billboard chart.

headline: Broths to Restore and Revive at Brodo
text: No doubt about it, Marco Canora really started something when he opened his first Brodo takeout window at Hearth, his East Village restaurant. That was two years ago, and now bone broth, spruced up with the Brodo label, is everywhere. Mr. Canora has expanded with a kiosk in Bryant Park, and he’s just opened a shop in the West Village where some basic broths are mixed and sometimes frothed with freshly milled herbs, Asian condiments, bone marrow, seaweed, butter and even cocoa. There are 11 preset seasoning combinations, $6 to $11, though customers can devise their own. Tom Yum, a combo with chicken broth, coconut milk, curry and chile oil, is becoming a favorite. The shop also sells basic broths, frozen, for home use: Brodo, 496 Hudson Street (Christopher Street), 212-366-0600, brodo.com.

headline: Kickback Case Questions Whether Valeant Was Victim or Participant
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International is a onetime Wall Street darling that has become a punching bag for how pharmaceutical firms drove up drug prices and engaged in questionable sales practices, in the process losing 90 percent of its market value. The first case to emerge from multiple federal and state investigations of its conduct, however, portrays it as a victim, not a perpetrator.

headline: Pope Francis, Trump, Japan: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Explaining the Other Side of Autumn Leaves
text: Q. As the autumn leaves change color, why is the top of a leaf the most colorful, sometimes bright red, while the underside is comparatively drab?

headline: Your Money Weekly: Solving the Mystery of the Stockbrokers
text: I love a good mystery, but it’s rare that we get to solve one in the world of personal finance.

headline: Cinematic Watering Holes
text: These bars are themed for sleeper hits and cult favorites.

headline: These Bars Want to Be in the Movies
text: The Overlook Lodge, a bar in the Pleasant Ridge neighborhood of Cincinnati, looks cozy enough at first, with wooden rafters and a fireplace big enough to sit inside.

headline: Travel Coloring Books for Grown-Ups
text: Forget coffee in the lobby and chocolates at turndown. Coloring books for grown-ups — where the illustrations are inspired by travel, fashion and Champagne wishes — are among the latest amenities being offered at hotels around the world.

headline: A Kit to Make Restaurant Pizza at Home
text: The chef Laurent Tourondel, who makes pizza in the wood-fueled ovens of L’Amico, is sharing the recipe with home cooks. With this kit you can nearly replicate the classic 12-inch pizza margherita from his Chelsea restaurant in a gas or electric oven. The dough is a breeze to handle, and =buffalo mozzarella, basil a tomato sauce with personality are included. Add a drizzle of good olive oil, chile flakes and whatever else you like on your pie with ingredients from your larder: Dough to Go, $14 for pickup only, L’Amico, 849 Avenue of the Americas (West 30th Street), 212-201-4065, lamico.nyc.

headline: Jurgen Klinsmann Fired as U.S. Soccer Coach
text: On Thursday, Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, dined with President Obama, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, a number of Nobel laureates and a couple of astronauts at a gala in Berlin. The sausages were “excellent,” he said.

headline: Breakfast, Lunch and Dessert in Jars
text: Food served in jars is not new, but Chloe Vichot, who fled finance for food and studied at culinary schools in New York along the way, has opened a shop dedicated exclusively to it. Ms. Vichot prepares and sells breakfast fare, bright lunch salads, soups, stews and desserts in glass jars, $5 to $14. Her specially made wide-mouth containers are more convenient than the usual Mason jars that some restaurants use to serve pâtés, desserts or even cocktails. The idea is to cut down on trash, and customers get a $1 discount for each jar they return (there is no jar deposit). The salads, in compact layers, are generous 22-ounce portions: Ancolie, 58 West Eighth Street (Avenue of the Americas), 646-524-5929, ancolie.co.

headline: Jeff Sessions’ Other Civil Rights Problem
text: In 1986, the Republican-dominated Senate Judiciary Committee torpedoed Ronald Reagan’s nomination of Jeff Sessions to the federal bench. As sworn testimony there revealed, Mr. Sessions, then the United States attorney for the Southern District of Alabama, had referred to the N.A.A.C.P. and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (founded by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.) as “un-American” and “Communist inspired.” He had joked that he thought the Ku Klux Klan was “O.K.” until he discovered some of its members smoked pot, and had accused a white attorney who supported voting rights of being a race traitor.

headline: A New Magazine Focuses on Food Preservation
text: Cured, a periodical about preserving food, is definitely a niche publication. An impressive roster of writers, including Betty Fussell, Jessica B. Harris, William Woys Weaver and Fuchsia Dunlop, covers a wealth of topics under the editorial direction of Darra Goldstein, an author and a founder of Gastronomica. Learn about a Swedish tradition of fermenting fish that dates back 9,000 years; making persimmon vinegar; the allure of stinky Chinese food; pickles in the Nishiki Market in Kyoto, Japan; and zur, a fermented Polish rye soup. As Ms. Goldstein put it, preserving is as important a development for humankind as cooking, a means of “hedging our bets against hunger.” The magazine is published by Zero Point Zero, the company that produces “The Mind of a Chef” and Anthony Bourdain’s “Parts Unknown”: Cured, $20 at some food shops, bookstores nationwide and from curedmagazine.com.

headline: Where Donald Trump Stands on School Choice, Student Debt and Common Core
text: When it comes to predicting how President-elect Donald J. Trump’s administration will affect America’s schools and universities, education experts say they are struggling to read the tea leaves.

headline: Fully Buzzed, This Coffee Helps Veterans
text: Detonate this new full-bodied coffee in your mug in the morning, and you’ll be fueled for the day. Bomb Coffee was founded by four friends, two of them veterans, and through the end of November, 22 percent of all sales will go to the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder and suicide prevention among veterans. The coffee, which they claim is high in caffeine, is grown in India and roasted in Rockford, Ill. The original is balanced, and the bourbon-infused variety has more complexity with a hint of booze: Bomb Coffee, whole bean or ground, $17.99 a pound or $19.99 a pound for bourbon-infused, $15.99 for 12 Keurig pods, bombcoffee.com.

headline: ‘We Shall Overcome’ Copyright Case Moves Closer to Trial
text: “We Shall Overcome” may be headed for a trial.

headline: Four Women’s Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
text: These pendants from Catherine Weitzman caught my eye among the endless pieces of jewelry and clothing I see every day in market appointments. The flowers within them are collected during trips around the world in places like the Canary Islands, Sri Lanka and Japan. And at Weitzman’s studio in Hawaii, the dried blooms are then protected in glass, sealed with either gold vermeil or recycled silver, and strung onto necklace chains — all one of a kind. $100-$205, available at catherineweitzman.com — ANGELA KOH

headline: Watch This 2006 Documentary About Rudy Giuliani
text: For those who didn’t live in New York City under the two-term mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, you might know him only as one of the heroes of 9/11. The man who held together a shattered metropolis. America’s Mayor. After a long stint out of the spotlight, Giuliani was back in the public eye on the campaign trail for Donald J. Trump. And now he’s one of President-elect Trump’s many candidates for a cabinet position.

headline: Mercury Is Shrinking, a ‘Great Valley’ Shows
text: A colossal canyon on Mercury may provide evidence that the tiny planet is shrinking.

headline: New Victory for World War II PT Boat: Restored and Museum-Ready
text: NEW ORLEANS — There was one hairy moment during PT 305’s slow-motion jaunt through downtown here on Saturday morning.

headline: Review: Lyon Opera Ballet Showcases Beethoven and Female Choreographers
text: LYON, France — Three dances. Three major choreographers. Three renditions of Beethoven’s “Grosse Fuge.” That’s the simple yet audacious idea behind the Lyon Opera Ballet’s “Trois Grandes Fugues,” which offers two pieces, by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker and Maguy Marin, already in its repertory, and a new work by the American choreographer Lucinda Childs.

headline: Bayer’s Essure Contraceptive Implant, Now With a Warning
text: Kim Myers used to compete in rodeo-style barrel horse races, but after being sterilized with an implantable device called Essure, the pain was so intense that she had to stop.

headline: Market Reaction to Deal May Bode Ill for Energy Transfer Partners
text: Energy Transfer investors are in another tangle. The pipeline partnership Sunoco Logistics Partners wants to buy Energy Transfer Partners for $21 billion, based on Friday’s closing prices. Energy Transfer Partners’ parent, Energy Transfer Equity, tied itself in knots trying to buy rival pipeline operator Williams Companies last year, before walking away on a technicality. The sour reaction to the latest deal suggests E.T.P. may also be headed for trouble.

headline: ‘Made in Sporting’: Lisbon Club’s Youth Academy Sets It Apart
text: LISBON — The way they tell the story at Sporting Lisbon, they did not even have to watch Cristiano Ronaldo play to know he was special. Seeing him with a ball at his feet, the quiet, skinny 12-year-old’s every effortless touch proof of his masterly control, was enough.

headline: Truman Capote’s Black and White Ball
text: Scenes from the iconic party of the 1960s, held at the Plaza hotel.

headline: 50 Years Ago, Truman Capote Hosted the Best Party Ever
text: What if you gave a party and everybody came? That is precisely what occurred on the drizzly night of Nov. 28, 1966, when 540 of Truman Capote’s nearest and dearest turned out for what the writer insisted on calling his “little masked ball for Kay Graham and all of my friends.”

headline: Earthquake Off Fukushima, Japan, Triggers Tsunami
text: TOKYO — A powerful earthquake triggered a tsunami off the coast of Japan early Tuesday, near where three nuclear reactors melted down at a plant in Fukushima after a quake and tsunami in 2011.

headline: Jason Moran, From the Venice Biennale to the Village Vanguard
text: A decade ago, when Jason Moran released “Artist in Residence,” it might have been possible to see that album as an outlier. Made up of selections from several large commissioned works — with a percussive cameo by the performance artist Joan Jonas, and a spoken-word sample of the conceptual artist Adrian Piper — it framed Mr. Moran as not only a pianist and composer but also a fluent traveler in the realm of contemporary art.

headline: What You Should Watch Monday Night
text: ‘Search Party,’ 11 p.m., TBS (New Series)

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Music, Movies and More
text: From “Pioneers of African-American Cinema” and “Freaks and Geeks” to the sounds of Kris Kristofferson and assorted Bad Boy artists, these gift ideas may enlighten, invigorate or simply stir up nostalgic memories.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Technology
text: It is often daunting to sort through the newest technology products to find something fitting for your gadget-savvy family and friends. Fret not: Here are some of the most useful and entertaining tech gifts of the year.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - T Magazine
text: Delightful presents big and small from the editors of T Magazine.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Wirecutter
text: We put in thousands of hours researching and testing products each year so we can make our readers' lives easier. Here we've collected a few of our favorites to make your gift giving just as simple, whether the people you love appreciate the practical or the whimisical.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Style
text: Buying gifts for your most stylish friends is harder than trying to get your teenage sister a Kylie Jenner lipkit. We got you, though. Here is a selection of items that will satisfy the women who has (nearly) everything and the man who is up on the latest trends.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Kids
text: A retro sled, a cozy hat, a build-it-yourself Bluetooth speaker — these are just a few of the fun, creative gifts we picked out for your little ones this holiday season. A selection of toys for children up to 12 years old.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Home
text: Gifts for the home are especially fitting during the holidays, as many of us open our doors to welcome family and friends. The following 15 new products go beyond the ordinary to offer equal parts functionality and delight — and, hopefully, a little extra joy throughout the year.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Food and Cooking
text: Food and the holidays go hand in hand, with everyone spending time happily eating or cooking or both. These gifts — from a sous-vide cooker for the tech-savvy gourmand to an adorable radish baby rattle for the teething future chef — celebrate those delights.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Travel
text: From a portable tea set to a sketchpad that saves your in-flight doodles, these gifts are guaranteed to become indispensable for your jet-setter friends.

headline: Find the Whale and the Bathroom With the Natural History Museum App
text: We’ve never camped out on its floors, as some people do, but my family has long had a fascination with the American Museum of Natural History. When I was 8 and 9 years old, I lived 21 blocks north of the fortresslike structure on Central Park West in Manhattan. And in those days, when not everyone had a television set, it became a delightful source of entertainment and what passed at that tender age for enlightenment.

headline: Exxon Mobil Accuses the Rockefellers of a Climate Conspiracy
text: Exxon Mobil, under fire over its past efforts to undercut climate science, is accusing the Rockefeller family of masterminding a conspiracy against it. Yes, that Rockefeller family.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Books
text: Books can transport us to exotic lands or ground us in sobering truths. Here, we have art catalogs, nonfiction books and novels, one of which might just be the right fit for someone on your list.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Experiences
text: Experiences make unique gifts, especially for those who are not crazy about things. Here's a selection that ranges from cultural to culinary, from the East Coast to the West. Or consider giving a donation to a group whose work is meaningful to your recipient.

headline: Review: ‘Furry!/La Furia!’ Goes Inside the Head of a Times Square Elmo
text: The young woman onstage is nervously glancing at the hulking Cookie Monster, who is standing way too close. He silently reveals a box cutter. The blade comes out: Click, click, click. He makes a stabbing motion. She lets out a profanity under her breath.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Credits
text: Present ideas, from technology to home goods, to make shopping easy this season.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide
text: Present ideas, from technology to home goods, to make shopping easy this season.

headline: Review: ‘Absolutely on Music’ Gives a Maestro a Stage for Ideas
text: “If there’s anything good about a major illness,” the Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa writes in an afterword to the oddly titled “Absolutely on Music,” “it’s that it gives you more time than you know what to do with.” He is referring to physical ailments that have plagued him since 2010, when he underwent surgery for esophageal cancer.

headline: Slain San Antonio Detective Was Targeted, Police Chief Says
text: A San Antonio police detective who was shot to death while sitting in a squad car was apparently killed just for being on the force, the city’s police chief said on Monday, a day after the detective and three officers were shot in separate episodes around the country.

headline: New York Seeks to Jump-Start College Savings by Giving Cash to Kindergartners’ Parents
text: Starting next fall, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio will create college savings accounts for thousands of New York City kindergartners, in a three-year pilot program intended to increase the number of low-income children who go on to attend college.

headline: Donald Trump, Pope Francis: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Letter from Alan Garten
text: A letter from Alan Garten, executive vice president and general counsel for the Trump Organization, stating that no funding for the Trump University settlement would come from Donald J. Trump's charitable foundation.

headline: Trump Foundation Won’t Pay Any of $25 Million University Settlement
text: Donald J. Trump’s charitable foundation will not be paying any of the $25 million settlement to resolve a series of lawsuits concerning Trump University, the president-elect’s defunct for-profit education venture that drew customer complaints about price gouging.

headline: Judges Find Wisconsin Redistricting Unfairly Favored Republicans
text: A panel of three federal judges said on Monday that the Wisconsin Legislature’s 2011 redrawing of State Assembly districts to favor Republicans was an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander, the first such ruling in three decades of pitched legal battles over the issue.

headline: Telling Mosquitoes Apart With a Cellphone
text: Simple cellphones can tell one type of mosquito from another by their hums, which may be useful in fighting mosquito-borne diseases, according to new research from Stanford University.

headline: William Trevor in The Times
text: William Trevor, the Irish novelist and master of the short story who died at 88 on Sunday, began his prolific writing career when he was in his mid-30s.

headline: Agency’s Green Card Errors Said to Be Worse Than First Thought
text: United States Citizenship and Immigration Services sent green cards to people that contained incorrect information or were duplicates, or mailed them to the wrong addresses, according to a report released on Monday by the Department of Homeland Security’s Office of Inspector General.

headline: At Least 5 Children Die in School Bus Crash in Chattanooga
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At least five children were killed on Monday afternoon when a school bus carrying nearly three dozen elementary school students overturned and crashed into a tree in Chattanooga, according to local officials.

headline: Review: ‘Among the Dead’ Deals in War and Family Mysteries
text: A shaggy white guy in a bellboy uniform knocks on the door of a hotel room in Seoul, South Korea, a little bumbling and out of place. He’s come to deliver a package to an American woman named Ana, but she thinks there must be some mistake: No one knows she’s there.

headline: As Donald Trump Picks His Cabinet
text: To the Editor:

headline: ISIS Used Chemical Arms at Least 52 Times in Syria and Iraq, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State has used chemical weapons, including chlorine and sulfur mustard agents, at least 52 times on the battlefield in Syria and Iraq since it swept to power in 2014, according to a new independent analysis.

headline: The Drama at ‘Hamilton,’ on Stage and Off
text: To the Editor:

headline: Honoring Obama’s Legacy: ‘Wisdom and Empathy’
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Little Red Book Train
text: A train totes books from The New York Public Library's research stacks beneath Bryant Park to the circulation desks on the first and third floors.

headline: Ukraine’s Detention of 2 Servicemen Ignites Dispute With Russia
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s Defense Ministry said Monday that Ukrainian Security Service operatives had abducted two of its servicemen, who were later described by Kiev as deserters from the Ukrainian Army.

headline: Law Firms, Struggling Financially, Cull Partner Ranks
text: To make partner at a big law firm is to grab a brass ring of prestige, wealth and security.

headline: Trump, on YouTube, Pledges to Create Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday released a two-and-a-half-minute infomercial-style video, turning to social media to deliver a direct-to-camera message in which he vowed to create jobs, renegotiate trade agreements, end restrictions on energy production and impose bans on lobbying.

headline: Below Bryant Park, a Bunker and a Train Line, Just for Books
text: This time of year, Bryant Park is flooded with holiday shoppers strolling amid the vending booths and skaters gliding on the ice rink.

headline: ‘A Rude Shock’: Indians Describe Life After Narendra Modi’s Currency Ban
text: A student in Malegaon in India’s western state of Maharashtra said he had to stand in line for six hours to exchange rupee notes banned by the government this month. By the time he got to the front, Junaid Ahmed said, the bank had run out of new bills.

headline: The Art of the Protest
text: Poland has one of the strictest abortion laws in Europe. Recently, a government-backed bill sought to go further, punishing women who had abortions with up to five years in prison. Last month, Polish women responded with a one-day strike. On Oct. 3, tens of thousands of people, most of them women dressed in black, protested in major cities.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
text: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Brooklyn Man Arrested, Accused of Supporting Islamic State
text: A Brooklyn man who tried to join the Islamic State and later told an informer that the group wanted to stage an attack in Times Square similar to the one that killed 86 people in Nice, France, last summer was arrested in New York on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: Small Banks Cheer Trump. So, After a Pause, Do Big Ones.
text: Washington lobbyists, financial and policy analysts and Wall Street insiders are all trying to figure out what the Trump administration will mean for the banking industry.

headline: ‘Hey, Cool Shoes’
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Mayor de Blasio Vows to Shield New Yorkers From Trump’s Policies
text: Faced with a Republican president-elect willing to draw hard lines on immigration, policing and funding for social programs, Mayor Bill de Blasio in a formal address on Monday drew some of his own, presenting New York City as a national model of resistance and “a better way.”

headline: With a Meeting, Trump Renewed a British Wind Farm Fight
text: LONDON — When President-elect Donald J. Trump met with the British politician Nigel Farage in recent days, he encouraged Mr. Farage and his entourage to oppose the kind of offshore wind farms that Mr. Trump believes will mar the pristine view from one of his two Scottish golf courses, according to one person present.

headline: U.N.’s Syria Envoy Suggests Donald Trump Has Limited Window to Work With Russia
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations special envoy to Syria offered unsolicited advice on Monday to President-elect Donald J. Trump: Pay attention to what happens between now and January in Syria, particularly in Aleppo, the storied city at risk of obliteration by Russian-backed Syrian forces.

headline: The 12 Classical Pieces Times Editors Recommend This Week
text: It’s been a long slog of a November. And you might not exactly be looking forward to the conversations pending over the Thanksgiving table.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Is Found Guilty of Cruelty to 100 Rabbits
text: A Brooklyn woman charged with abusing the residents of her sprawling rabbit colony was convicted on Monday of 100 counts of animal cruelty — one for each rabbit the jury found to have suffered under her care.

headline: Review: ‘My Name Is Gideon: I’m Probably Going to Die, Eventually’
text: The first time I encountered Gideon Irving, he was accosting my wife.

headline: Fake News Onslaught Targets Pizzeria as Nest of Child-Trafficking
text: WASHINGTON — Days before the presidential election, James Alefantis, owner of a local pizza restaurant called Comet Ping Pong, noticed an unusual spike in the number of his Instagram followers.

headline: Civil Rights Groups Call on Trump to Denounce Racism of Alt-Right
text: WASHINGTON — Civil rights groups called on President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday to publicly condemn extremist movements that are espousing racism in his name after hundreds of white nationalist sympathizers spent the weekend in Washington debating ways to preserve white culture.

headline: Jurgen Klinsmann Promised a Lot for U.S. Soccer. But Did He Deliver?
text: About two years ago, during an interview at a country club in Southern California, Jurgen Klinsmann spoke at length about what he considered to be “success” when it came to his job as coach of the United States national team.

headline: Trump Summons TV Figures for Private Meeting, and Lets Them Have It
text: It had all the trappings of a high-level rapprochement: President-elect Donald J. Trump, now the nation’s press critic in chief, inviting the leading anchors and executives of television news to join him on Monday for a private meeting of minds.

headline: Donald Trump’s Business Dealings Test a Constitutional Limit
text: WASHINGTON — Not long after he took office, President Obama sought advice from the Justice Department about a potential conflict of interest involving a foreign government. He wanted to know whether he could accept the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Investors Make Bullish Bet on Trump, and an Era of Tax Cuts and Spending
text: Two weeks after Donald J. Trump swept to victory, investors from around the world are betting that his promises of tax cuts, fewer regulations and a spendthrift federal government can recharge the American economy.

headline: Grievances and Grumblings, Long Before Chris Christie’s Fall in Donald Trump’s Circle
text: The critical weekend before Election Day was set to be a busy one for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey; he was to campaign for Donald J. Trump in the battleground states of New Hampshire and Pennsylvania.

headline: Myanmar’s War on the Rohingya
text: Myanmar has long persecuted the country’s Rohingya Muslim minority, denying it basic rights to citizenship, to marry, to worship and to an education. After violence unleashed in 2012 by Buddhist extremists drove tens of thousands of Rohingya out of their homes, many risked their lives to escape in smugglers’ boats; more than 100,000 others are living in squalid internment camps. Now, a counterinsurgency operation by Myanmar’s military is again forcing thousands of Rohingya to abandon their villages.

headline: Stars to Remember, Even if First Time on Hall of Fame Ballot Is Their Last
text: There are 19 new names on the Hall of Fame ballot, released Monday and landing soon in the mailboxes of more than 400 veteran baseball writers. There are also 15 holdovers still seeking the magic threshold — 75 percent of the vote — needed for election.

headline: Trump’s Focus on Generals for Top Jobs Stirs Worries Over Military’s Sway
text: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump ran for president boasting that he knew more about fighting terrorists than America’s generals.

headline: At Jewelry Arabia, the Maharani
text: “I wanted to use as many diamonds as possible,” Tarang Arora, the creative director of Amrapali Jewels, said about the showpiece he had in mind for Jewelry Arabia 2016.

headline: Yale Dean at Center of Protests Is Leaving for Northwestern
text: The dean of Yale College, Jonathan Holloway, announced on Monday that he was stepping down at the end of the academic year to become provost of Northwestern University.

headline: In Antwerp, Tapping into a World of Jewelry Inspiration
text: Martine Hul is the self-appointed queen of pavé diamonds.

headline: Argentina to Face Croatia, and History of Heartbreak, in Quest for First Davis Cup
text: Good things do come to tennis players who wait, as Andy Murray reminded us this month by finally reaching No. 1 at age 29.

headline: Moving Jewelry Sales Online in India
text: BANGALORE, India — When Sushma Sonty wanted to buy herself some jewelry for her birthday, she didn’t head to a traditional jeweler, as is the custom in India, or even to a local store. Instead, she turned to Melorra, a new website that marries Western fast-fashion trends with wearable fine jewelry.

headline: Louisa Guinness, a Life in Art Jewelry
text: It started almost as a whimsy. Then it took over her life.

headline: Suit Calling War on ISIS Illegal Is Rejected
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday dismissed a lawsuit that accused President Obama of waging an illegal war against the Islamic State, clearing the way for the conflict to continue under President-elect Donald J. Trump without explicit congressional authorization.

headline: Boghossian Keeps Jewelry in the Family
text: GENEVA — From their small, unmarked headquarters, the Boghossian family looks out over the Rhône River, directly facing the globally recognized jewelers of Geneva and their logo-emblazoned waterfront towers. The competition, though colossal, seems to mean little to them and their young high-jewelry brand.

headline: Review: ‘This Day Forward,’ a Weird Wedding Night and What Comes After
text: Nicky Silver is driving with the brakes on in “This Day Forward,” his bumpy and tentative new comedy, which opened on Monday night at the Vineyard Theater. Usually, for better or worse, this mordant playwright can be relied on to go tearing through the barricades of good taste, good manners and sane plotting into his own ecstatic no man’s land of misery.

headline: But So Delicious
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This may come as a surprise to some, but in addition to being totally delicious, BACON was used in World War II to manufacture bombs. That’s right; when the fat was rendered and turned into glycerin, you could blow up a lot of things with it.

headline: Lack of Protocol Added to Chaos During J.F.K. Scare, Inquiry Finds
text: A joint New York State and federal investigation into how false reports of gunfire at Kennedy International Airport in August led to mass panic found security protocols seriously lacking, with poor coordination between agencies and widely divergent levels of training for security personnel exacerbating the chaos.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s sad to say, but a lot of times when you go to these competitions, you’re like: Just get close enough to top three because you never know who’s going to test positive.”

headline: The Village of Flowers — and Watches
text: About a third of the residents of Fleurier, Switzerland, work in the watch industry.

headline: Fleurier, a Swiss Watch Company Town
text: Ever wonder why some watch companies have the word “Fleurier” attached to their names?

headline: To Snag Snapchat Spectacles in New York, a Long, Cold Wait
text: New Yorkers have been known to queue up for many a hot-ticket item: dinner reservations, iPhones, Cronuts.

headline: Simcha Felder, Rogue Democratic Senator, Will Remain Loyal to G.O.P.
text: For the last four years, New York Democrats have had to contend with an only-in-Albany riddle: In a 63-member State Senate with slightly more Democrats than there are Republicans, how do the Republicans manage to hold a majority?

headline: Kanye West Is Hospitalized for ‘Psychiatric Emergency’ Hours After Canceling Tour

text: NEW CASTLE, Del. — The nearby factory that made Dodge Durangos closed eight years ago. The General Motors Boxwood Road Plant — open since 1947 — closed the next year. So did the oil refinery in Delaware City.

headline: Fellow Trump Critics, Maybe Try a Little Listening
text: I’ve been thinking a lot about the best imaginable Trump voter. This is the Trump supporter who wasn’t motivated by racism or bigotry. This is the one who cringed every time Donald Trump did something cruel, vulgar or misogynistic.

headline: Not Your Grandmother’s Wisconsin
text: Milwaukee — I love telling people I’m from Wisconsin. Maybe it’s my defense mechanism for when people accuse me of being a coastal elite, out of touch with Real America. I like fulfilling all the Wisconsin stereotypes. I love cheese and cheese curds, of course. I love our sports teams out of a vague sense of homerism. And my accent (all hard A’s) comes out in full force after ah coupl’ah beers.

headline: Don’t Retreat Into Fortress America
text: Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson’s memoir, “Present at the Creation,” is a classic account of how a durable and productive Atlantic alliance, based on common values and a cleareyed judgment of America’s strategic interests, rebuilt Europe after World War II and produced international institutions responsible for the security and expanding economic opportunities that have been of such benefit to the United States.

headline: Donald Trump Rages, at the Wrong Target
text: Millions of Americans are justifiably frightened by the tide of racism, anti-Semitism and xenophobia that has swept the country since the election of Donald Trump, whose campaign stoked these views and who named Stephen Bannon of Breitbart News his chief strategist in the White House.

headline: Rarely Seen Photos by Jack London
text: One hundred years ago today, Jack London died in Sonoma County, Calif., at the age of 40. He was famous for novels, like the “The Call of the Wild,” which were based on his adventures, trekking through the Klondike or sailing the South Pacific. He was the archetype of the macho writer — before Ernest Hemingway — having been, among other things, a Socialist, a hobo, a sailor, a war correspondent and an oyster pirate.

headline: A New Look at Civilian Life in Europe Under Hitler

headline: Should Parents Be Expected to Donate to a Public School?
text: Our granddaughter is in kindergarten at a highly ranked elementary school: Test scores average in the top 1 percent of the schools in the state. Only 1.2 percent of the students are on a free or low-cost lunch. A sheet is passed out to parents of all students in the school from the parents’ organization at the beginning of the school year. Last year they pressured parents to donate $600 per year per student enrolled. This year the amount has been raised to $1,000. The parents’ organization keeps the books and clearly knows which parents have paid in full and which have not.

headline: Is Social Media Disconnecting Us From the Big Picture?
text: Maybe I shouldn’t have been surprised that Donald Trump could be elected president, but I was. I live in Brooklyn and work in Manhattan, two of the most liberal places in the country. But even online, I wasn’t seeing many signs of support for him. How did that blindness occur? Social media is my portal into the rest of the world — my periscope into the communities next to my community, into how the rest of the world thinks and feels. And it completely failed me.

headline: Amaro for Everyone
text: Don’t be bitter, we’re told. But in American cocktail culture — especially its most rarefied, la-di-da precincts — bitterness has become a signifier of sophistication and discernment. A decade ago, bar patrons who wished to make it clear that they weren’t into the sweet stuff might have requested something on the dry side or the sour side. Now they’re as likely to want it bitter.

headline: Steven Johnson on How Play Shaped the World
text: WONDERLANDHow Play Made the Modern WorldBy Steven Johnson322 pp. Riverhead Books. $30.

headline: Billionaires vs. the Press in the Era of Trump
text: In 2005, Tim O’Brien, then a financial reporter at The New York Times, published the book “TrumpNation: The Art of Being the Donald.” O'Brien talked to sources with an up-close view of Donald J. Trump’s finances, who concluded that the real-estate developer’s net worth was $150 million to $250 million, rather than the $2 billion to $5 billion Trump had variously claimed. Trump, who had courted O’Brien by taking him for rides in his Ferrari and private jet, sued O’Brien for libel in New Jersey in 2006. Trump called O’Brien a “wack job” on the “Today” show — while, O’Brien says, continuing to curry favor with him privately. O’Brien’s publisher, Warner Books, was also named in the suit and hired top lawyers who put Trump through an unsparing two-day deposition. Asked about his finances, Trump was caught lying or exaggerating 30 times. “He thought he’d get a friendly judge, and we would roll over,” says O’Brien, who is now the executive editor of Bloomberg View. “We didn’t.” The case went through four judges and was dismissed in 2009.

headline: How Conservative Sites Turn Celebrity Despair on Its Head
text: Throughout this bitter election campaign, liberal celebrities like Lady Gaga, Jennifer Lawrence, Lena Dunham and Lin-Manuel Miranda used their powerful media platforms to sing Hillary Clinton’s praises. Now they’ve invited their online followers to join them in processing her loss and protesting the impending administration of Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Carefree Getaway Just Off the Persian Gulf
text: As a ferocious, record-breaking blizzard pummeled our windows, ushering in yet another month of Moscow’s winter, we began a sudden, frantic search for a sunny refuge, someplace to both defrost on the beach and absorb a little culture over the course of four days.

headline: A Four-Day Feast in Philadelphia
text: If you are looking to reclaim a coherent sense of America after this nervous breakdown of an election season, let me suggest that eating your way through Philadelphia is a fine way to start.

headline: For Deaf Tennis Player, Sound Is No Barrier
text: ASAN, South Korea — To improve its chances in the boys’ team tennis event at the National Sports Festival here, Mapo High School in Seoul brought in a ringer from Jecheon, two hours southeast of the capital. His name was Lee Duck-hee, and he had first caught the coach’s eye when he was in elementary school.

headline: Zika Looms in Asia, Tempered by a Fuller View of Its Dangers
text: The Zika virus caught the world’s attention last year after experts noticed that a small percentage of women carrying the virus in Latin America were giving birth to children with microcephaly, a defect that causes malformed heads and severely stunts brain development. The virus is now endemic there, and scientists fear that caseloads may spike again during the hot, wet months of the Southern Hemisphere’s summer, which begins in December.

headline: A Warlord’s Cuddly Makeover, With a Nod to Donald Trump
text: MOSCOW — Caucasian warlord, mixed martial arts enthusiast, scourge of any opposition — Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the autocratic leader of a turbulent mountain republic, wants to convince the rest of Russia that its image of him is all wrong.

text: LONDON — Once again, President-elect Donald J. Trump seems to have gone out of his way to embarrass the British government.

headline: Jogging the Brain
text: The holiday season is a good time for a reminder that alcohol can do bad things to the brain. Studies on animals suggest that it reduces the number of neurons in the hippocampus, the brain’s memory center, and weakens mitochondria there. Because mitochondria help produce energy within cells, their impairment can damage or kill brain cells. But two new animal studies offer some succor: Aerobic exercise, it turns out, may meliorate some of the impacts of heavy drinking on the brain.

headline: South Korean Leader, Amid Scandal, Approves Intelligence Pact With Japan
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye on Tuesday approved a military intelligence-sharing pact with Japan aimed at countering the North Korean threat, a move that angered South Korean opposition parties, which want to impeach Ms. Park over a corruption scandal.

headline: Art for East Germany’s Secret Police Is for Sale in Miami
text: An art historian in Germany has unearthed a three-ton, 65-foot-wide stained glass mural that was created in the early 1980s for the headquarters of the East German secret police, or Stasi, and had been forgotten in a shipping container for 24 years. It will go on sale at a temporary exhibition space in Miami to coincide with the Art Basel Miami Beach contemporary art fair next week, with a price tag of $21.4 million — which some historians said was out of line with its value.

headline: Mexico Doesn’t Have to Appease Trump. It Can Fight Back.
text: This year, for the first time since Ronald Reagan assailed the Soviet Union in 1980, an American presidential candidate actively campaigned against another country’s national interests. By threatening to deport all undocumented immigrants, about half of whom are Mexican; to build a wall on the Mexican border; and to rip up the North American Free Trade Agreement, which is far more important for Mexico than for the United States, Donald J. Trump made Mexico one of the central issues of the campaign.

headline: Regular Milk May Beat Low Fat for Kids
text: Low-fat milk may not be the best option for kids, though many experts recommend it to fight obesity for children over 2.

headline: College Advice for the Cost of a Single Post-it Note

headline: The States That College Graduates Are Most Likely to Leave
text: This year’s election has forced Americans to take notice of class divisions between workers. And while these divisions may at first ring of lazy stereotypes — the rural Rust Belt worker without a college degree and the coastal urban college-educated worker — they’re rooted in a real dynamic. Many of the most skilled workers — young people with college degrees — are leaving struggling regions of America for cities, specifically for cities in Southern and coastal states.

headline: A 150-Year-Old British Footwear Factory, Through the Lens of Martin Parr
text: Long the preserve of fusty country gents, the venerable British footwear brand Grenson has enjoyed a renaissance in the hands of the designer Tim Little; its sturdy handmade shoes and boots are now prized by footwear fetishists from Hackney to Tokyo. This year, the label is celebrating its 150th birthday — in understated British fashion. It has re-editioned eight styles from the last century, including an awkward-looking orthopedic Oxford from the 1930s named the “Grenson Joy Step” and a 1940s infantryman’s boot.

headline: New Quake Tests Resilience, and Faith, in Japan’s Nuclear Plants
text: TOKYO — There was no avoiding fearful memories of the Japanese nuclear disaster of 2011 on Tuesday morning after a powerful earthquake off the coast of Fukushima caused a cooling system in a nuclear plant to stop, leaving more than 2,500 spent uranium fuel rods at risk of overheating.

headline: Having Turned a Corner, Washington’s NoMa Is Coming Alive
text: WASHINGTON — Outfitted with a trendy name and infused with the enthusiasm of developers and city planners, the NoMa neighborhood here had high hopes riding on it as it took shape a decade ago.

headline: A Crumpled School Bus Leaves Chattanooga Dazed
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Jasmine Mateen was standing outside her home here on Tuesday afternoon when her cellphone went off: Two of her daughters, who were injured when their school bus crashed on Monday, were being discharged from the hospital.

headline: The Great Big World of a Minimalist Lighting Designer
text: Michael Anastassiades’s lighting and furniture are the very picture of minimalism, but the designer dislikes the limited nature of the word. “I like to start broadly with my research and take information away,” says the London-based Cypriot. “It’s a distillation process.” His uncompromising aesthetic — a blend of clever functionality and spare organic beauty — has earned the 49-year-old a loyal following. His Calder-inspired mobiles and spheres are sold in such design meccas as the Future Perfect and Ralph Pucci, and he has collaborated with FlOS and the Parisian fashion boutique Colette.

headline: Vegas Golden Knights, N.H.L.’s New Team, Take Their Place on the Strip
text: In an office building in suburban Las Vegas, an N.H.L. franchise is taking shape.

headline: Donald Trump Drops Threat of New Hillary Clinton Investigation
text: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that he had no intention of pressing for an investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server or the financial operations of her family’s foundation, dropping the “lock her up” pledge that became a rallying cry for his campaign for the White House.

headline: Land Mine Casualties Jump 75% as Funding for Their Removal Declines
text: Despite a global treaty that bans land mines, casualties from those weapons and other unexploded munitions lurking in current and past war zones rose sharply last year to the highest point in a decade, a monitoring group said Tuesday in its annual report.

headline: What Will Trump Trade Policy Actually Look Like? Three Possibilities
text: Donald J. Trump, through decades in public life, has been consistent on one core policy idea: that the United States has gotten a raw deal from its major trading partners in the agreements that bind their economies. Renegotiating those terms will surely be a top priority for his administration.

headline: Your Phone Carries Chemical Clues About You, but There Are Limits to Using Them
text: Your phone is pretty much a high-tech bucket of germs. Thousands of microscopic bugs crawl around on its surface. Remnants of dirty, old skin cells smudge its cover. Tiny hairs stick inside its buttons. And your hands have smeared hundreds of chemicals across its surface. The foundation on your face, the antidepressants you take, the shampoo in your shower and even the hard-core mosquito repellent you applied down in Panama four months ago: All of these things leave traces on your hands and phone. That’s why scientists say they can use your phone to learn a lot about your lifestyle.

headline: In Turnaround, Raiders Close In on Winning Season, Maybe More
text: Oakland Raiders fans got a dose of hope last season when, under a dynamic new coach, Jack Del Rio, their long-moribund team finished at 7-9, a sharp improvement after 4-12, 4-12 and 3-13 seasons. Still, it was their 13th straight year without a trip to the N.F.L. playoffs.

headline: David Hockney to Design Stained-Glass Window for Queen Elizabeth

headline: At a School of Immigrants, Challenges Reach Far Beyond the Classroom
text: Sometimes during assemblies at Public School 160, in South Brooklyn, the principal, Margaret Russo, will ask, “Who was born in another country?” Many hands will go up.

headline: How to Upgrade Your Thanksgiving Road Trip
text: While talk of Thanksgiving travel often centers around the cost and tribulations of flying, during the holiday weekend more Americans actually hit the road.  AAA estimated that nearly 90 percent of Thanksgiving travelers will go by automobile this year, with about 48.7 million people driving 50 miles or more from home. That’s up nearly 2 percent over 2015, and the most Thanksgiving travelers since 2007. So why not make the journey more enjoyable? After all, you could spend hours sitting in traffic. Or maybe dinner at your cousin’s house wasn’t as tasty, er, filling, as you had hoped. Everyone knows to bring along the usual accessories, like phone chargers and tablet mounts. But certain extras can help shift a ho-hum road trip into the next gear. Below, a guide.

headline: One Holiday, and Countless Ways to Say Thanks
text: If you happen by Stacy Christopher’s home in Santa Barbara, Calif., early on Thanksgiving Day, you may think that her husband, her son and their guests chose an odd time for yard work. They rummage through the greenery. They cart away branches.

headline: Bruce Arena, Replacing Jurgen Klinsmann as U.S. Coach, Keeps Things Simple
text: The once and future coach — Bruce Arena — will try to make it sound simple. Even at 65, he will roll his eyes and sneer at complicated questions about strategy and formations. This masks his feel of the game, buys him time and distance.

headline: Thai Food Strikes Out in a Fresh Direction at Fish Cheeks
text: In the early days of Thai cuisine in the United States, when pad Thai and spring rolls were exotic treats, Americans fell hard for the interlocking tastes of lime, fish sauce, chiles and herbs. Over the years, that love has grown lukewarm. Many of the restaurants weren’t very good to begin with, and watered-down, sloppy Americanized versions of dishes from central Thailand were the only Thai food many Americans knew.

headline: Lithuania’s New Prime Minister Pledges to Increase Military Spending
text: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Lawmakers in Lithuania chose as their new prime minister on Tuesday a former police chief and interior minister who supports Donald J. Trump’s call for NATO members to spend more on defense.

headline: What 10 Actors Wore to a Spike Lee Casting Call in Brooklyn
text: Few filmmakers are linked to a borough the way that Spike Lee is to Brooklyn. So when Mr. Lee, the 59-year-old director, announced that he was having an open casting call for a coming Netflix series based on “She’s Gotta Have It” last month, Brooklynites of all stripes turned out. The line of actors and performers at the Masonic Temple was so long that it wrapped around an entire block in Fort Greene. Despite the wait, the crowd was in good spirits and, naturally, smartly dressed.
